revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name =Joe Kryczka |image =Joe Kryczka judge portrait.jpg |alt =Black and white portrait of Kryczka in judicial robe with white collar |birth_date ={{Birth date|1935|06|04}} |birth_place =[[Coleman, Alberta]], Canada |death_date ={{Death date and age|1991|01|11|1935|06|04}} |death_place =[[Calgary]], Alberta, Canada |resting_place=St. Mary's Cemetery, Calgary |alma_mater =[[University of Alberta]] |occupation =Lawyer, Justice on the [[Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta]] |known_for =[[Canadian Amateur Hockey Association|CAHA]] and [[Hockey Alberta|AAHA]] president
1972 [[Summit Series]] negotiator
[[1988 Winter Olympics]] bid |awards =[[Canada's Sports Hall of Fame]]
[[Alberta Sports Hall of Fame and Museum|Alberta Sports Hall of Fame]] }} '''Joseph Julius Kryczka''' {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|QC}} ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|k|r|ɪ|s|k|ɑː}}; June 4, 1935 – January 11, 1991) was a Canadian [[ice hockey]] administrator, lawyer and judge, who was commonly known as "'''Justice Joe'''".{{cite web|url=http://ashfm.ca/hall-of-fame-honoured-members/in-memory/kryczka-joseph|title=Kryczka, Joseph|website=Alberta Sports Hall of Fame & Museum|access-date=2018-07-12}}{{cite web|url=http://hockeygods.com/images/11793-Joe_Kryczka_and_Adam_Kryczka_University_of_Alberta_Golden_Bears|title=Joe Kryczka and Adam Kryczka University of Alberta Golden Bears|date=2014-03-16|website=HockeyGods|access-date=2018-07-14}}{{cite web |url=http://www.1972summitseries.com/kryczka.html|title=Joe Kryczka|website=1972 Summit Series|access-date=2018-07-13}}{{cite news|title=Kryczka dead|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=January 15, 1991|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/obituary-clipping-jan-15-1991-765680/}}{{free access}} His hockey career included tenures as president of the [[Hockey Alberta|Alberta Amateur Hockey Association]], and later the [[Canadian Amateur Hockey Association]] from 1971 to 1973. He began his legal career as a lawyer, then was appointed a judge, and later elevated to a justice on the [[Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta]]. Kryczka was the lead negotiator who secured the agreement for [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada]] to play the [[Soviet Union national ice hockey team|Soviet Union]] at the 1972 [[Summit Series]]. His negotiating skills were unrecognized at the time, and his contribution to the Summit Series was overshadowed by [[Alan Eagleson]]. During his career he negotiated other notable disagreements in Canadian hockey. When the [[Western Hockey League|Western Canada Hockey League]] broke away from the governing body, Kryczka was able to reunite the league with the rest of Canada, and maintain the threatened the [[Memorial Cup]] competition. He also successfully brought Alberta hockey back under the national umbrella when it resigned. He later dealt with the [[World Hockey Association]] when it raided rosters of Canadian junior teams without compensation, and then became the first commissioner of the [[Canadian Hockey League|Canadian Major Junior Hockey League]]. Kryczka graduated from the [[University of Alberta]], and played hockey with the [[Alberta Golden Bears and Pandas|Golden Bears]]. He practiced law in [[Calgary]] for over 20 years, was a director with the [[Calgary Cowboys]], and later played a key role with Calgary's successful bid for the [[1988 Winter Olympics]]. He was later inducted into both [[Canada's Sports Hall of Fame]] and the [[Alberta Sports Hall of Fame and Museum|Alberta Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1990. ==Early life== [[File:Coleman, Alberta.jpg|thumb|right|Kryczka was born and raised in the village of Coleman, Alberta.]] Kryczka was born June 4, 1935, in [[Coleman, Alberta]].''Mardson, Austin & Ernest (2011)'', p. 102{{cite web|url=http://www.sportshall.ca/honoured-members/honoured-members-search.html?proID=398&catID=all&lang=fr|title=Honoured Member Joe Kryczka|website=Canada's Sports Hall of Fame|access-date=2018-07-12}}{{cite news|title=Kryczka (Obituary)|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=January 14, 1991|page=2 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jan-14-1991-752629/}}{{free access}} He grew up playing minor ice hockey until the juvenile age level in Coleman,{{cite news|title=Juveniles Setback Coleman 3-2|newspaper=Drumheller Mail|location=Drumheller, Alberta|date=March 12, 1952|last=Naegeli|first=George|page=1 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-mar-12-1952-764939/}}{{free access}} and was captain of the juvenile team in the 1951–52 season.{{cite news|title=Coleman Bows To Drumheller|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=March 17, 1952|page=10|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-mar-17-1952-764947/}}{{free access}} He attended Coleman High School, and received a bursary from the [[Elks of Canada]] for having the highest marks in grade nine.{{cite news|title=Five scholarships presented to Coleman High School students|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald |location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=October 16, 1950|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-16-1950-764931/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Coleman Students Are Honored|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald |location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=October 18, 1950|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-18-1950-764933/}}{{free access}} He graduated with honours in 1953 as the class [[valedictorian]].{{cite news|title=Coleman Graduates Are Honored|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=July 7, 1953|page=15 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jul-07-1953-764951/}}{{free access}} Kryczka enrolled at [[University of Alberta]] in 1953, and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1957. He was active in student life, serving as president of both the [[political science]] and law clubs, and was secretary of the [[student council]]. He played junior baseball for his Coleman team in summers.{{cite news|title=Yorks Gain Split in Junior Doubleheader|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=July 11, 1955|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jul-11-1955-764962/}}{{free access}} He played three seasons of ice hockey as a [[defenceman]] with the [[Alberta Golden Bears and Pandas|Golden Bears]], and was teammates with his brother Adam in 1955.{{cite news|title=Pass Students Get Varsity Awards|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=March 30, 1955|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-mar-30-1955-764957/}}{{free access}} He earned two [[varsity letter]]s in university, but a shoulder injury ended his playing career. He completed his [[law degree]] in 1958 at the University of Alberta.{{cite web|url=https://www.westernwheel.com/article/oiler-proud-of-familys-summit-series-legacy-20121003|title=Oiler proud of family’s Summit Series legacy|last=Greer|first=Remy|date=2012-10-03|website=Okotoks Western Wheel|access-date=2018-07-14}} The university awarded him a gold ring for scholastic achievements, and received the Lorne Calhoun Memorial Award for contributions to student activities. Kryczka became an [[articled clerk]] in Calgary under future [[Court of Appeal of Alberta]] justice David Clifton Prowse, and was [[Admission to practice law|called to the bar]] in 1959. He was originally associated with the law firm of [[Peter Lougheed]] in the early 1960s, and then became a partner of Mason and Kryczka. He later served as vice-president of the [[Alberta Liberal Party|Alberta Young Liberal Association]] in 1966,{{cite news|title=McDonald Back As Liberal Leader|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge|date=January 17, 1966|page=2 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/politics-clipping-jan-17-1966-764976/}}{{free access}} and continued to practice law in Calgary until 1980. ==Alberta hockey== Kryczka began volunteering as community hockey coach in 1959, and also [[Official (ice hockey)|refereed]] in various leagues. He was elected to the executive committee of the [[Hockey Alberta|Alberta Amateur Hockey Association]] (AAHA) in 1963, and served as the Calgary [[Boosterism|Booster Club]] president from 1964 to 1965.''Calgary Booster Club (1986)'', p. 5 He was elected second vice-president of the AAHA in September 1966,{{cite news|title=Stu Peppard Is Returned|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=September 26, 1966|page=12|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-26-1966-764987/}}{{free access}} and became its president in October 1967.{{cite news|title=Talking About Sports|newspaper=Peace River Record Gazette|location=Peace River, Alberta|date=October 4, 1967|last=Windjack|first=Fred|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-04-1967-764996/}}{{free access}} Kryczka's presidency of the AAHA coincided with the formation of the [[Western Hockey League|Western Canada Hockey League]] (WCHL), which had teams in [[Alberta]], [[Saskatchewan]] and [[Manitoba]]. Various disputes arose with the WCHL, because it was outside of the jurisdiction of the [[Canadian Amateur Hockey Association]] (CAHA), the governing body for the AAHA. In February 1969, the CAHA and Kryczka as president of the AAHA, were named in a lawsuit by the WCHL and its governing body, the Canadian Hockey Association.{{cite news|title=Alberta Court To Rule|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=February 18, 1969|page=24|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-18-1969-765068/}}{{free access}} The WCHL sought development money for its players drafted by the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), as per the draft agreement between the NHL and the CAHA, but the CAHA refused to distribute money to a league it did not sanction. Later that month, Kryczka gave an ultimatum to the Alberta Hockey Referees Association, stating that the AAHA would only use referees which did not officiate in the WCHL.{{cite news|title=AAHA ultimatum is given to refs|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=February 24, 1969|page=11|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-24-1969-765085/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Alberta Referees Adamant|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=February 25, 1969|page=28|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-25-1969-765088/}}{{free access}} The decision threatened to end an agreement from October 1968, where referees in Alberta formed an independent organization to officiates games for both governing bodies. Later in March, Kryczka suspended two referees who still worked games in the WCHL.{{cite news|title=Two refs cannot work senior tilts|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=March 5, 1969|page=8|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-mar-05-1969-765094/}}{{free access}} At the 1969 CAHA annual general meeting, Kryczka said that the WCHL succeeded in drawing many fans, and gave an opportunity for many young men to play in [[Western Canada]]. He also felt that CAHA branches such as Alberta, should be able to establish a major junior category for higher-level competition, similar to what the WCHL did across three provinces.{{cite news|title=Hockey Bodies Nearing Peace?|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=May 20, 1969|page=11|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-20-1969-765108/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=CAHA tries to lure CHA back into fold|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=May 21, 1969|last=Krevenchuk|first=Walter|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-21-1969-765344/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=CAHA courting WCHL?|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 21, 1969|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-21-1969-765347/}}{{free access}} The CAHA reorganized its committees to give more representation at the national level to its leagues, but the motion to have a major junior classification was defeated.{{cite news|title=CAHA shuffles organization|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 23, 1969|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-23-1969-765628/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=CAHA Keeps Its Junior Format|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 23, 1969|last=Krevenchuk|first=Walter|page=49|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-23-1969-765636/}}{{free access}} ==CAHA vice-president== [[File:Memorial Cup.jpg|thumb|right|The Memorial Cup is awarded to the junior ice hockey champion of Canada, and its status was threatened in 1971 while Kryczka was vice-president of the CAHA.]] Kryczka was elected vice-president of the CAHA in May 1969.{{cite news|title=CAHA reorganizes after 53 years|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=May 23, 1969|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-23-1969-765645/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Talking About Sports|newspaper=Peace River Record Gazette|location=Peace River, Alberta|date=June 11, 1969|last=Windjack|first=Fred|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-11-1969-765650/}}{{free access}} In September 1969, he was optimistic that the CAHA and the WCHL would be able to agree on reuniting. He felt it would be possible if the WCHL agreed to appropriately compensate CAHA teams from which players were signed, and that there would be no expansion into cities with an existing CAHA team.{{cite news|title=Trouble Lies Within CAHA's Ranks, Munro|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 9, 1969|page=74 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-09-1969-765655/}}{{free access}} He further confirmed that the CAHA had not approved of its players being signed by the WCHL, or relocation into its territory. He said that the CAHA would not agree to those demands of the WCHL, which are against CAHA regulations.{{cite news|title=AJHL Head Man Denies Threat|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 16, 1969|page=54|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-16-1969-765669/}}{{free access}} Later in 1969, Canada and the CAHA withdrew from play in the [[Ice Hockey World Championships]] over a dispute with the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] (IIHF) regarding the use of professionals, which began a continuing feud between Kryczka, and IIHF president [[Bunny Ahearne]].{{cite news|title=CAHA Still Awaiting Invitation|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 3, 1971|page=21 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-03-1971-766393/}}{{free access}} The CAHA added multiple vice-presidents as of 1970, and Kryczka was elected first vice-president by acclamation on May 29, 1970.{{cite news|title=Earl Dawson Re-Elected|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 29, 1970|page=44|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-29-1970-766234/}}{{free access}} He took objection to [[Clarence Campbell]] stating that the NHL may need to revert back to direct ownership of teams, because of concessions made to the WCHL, and having different age limits across Canada's junior hockey system. Kryczka felt that the CAHA adequately resolved its disagreements with the WCHL, and did not need NHL personnel getting involved.{{cite news|title=Clarence Campbell says NHL may revert to sponsorship|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=October 31, 1970|page=6 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-31-1970-766314/}}{{free access}} He stated that the [[1971 Memorial Cup]] would not likely be played, due to the [[Ontario Hockey League|Ontario Hockey Association Junior A division]] and the [[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League|Quebec Junior Hockey League]] being in disagreement with the number overage players in the WCHL.{{cite news|title=Memorial Cup unlikely|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=February 22, 1971|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-22-1971-766346/}}{{free access}} He mentioned the potential for changing regulations at the upcoming general meeting, requiring teams to agree to the competition in order to receive development funds from the NHL agreement. ==CAHA president== ===First year=== Kryczka succeeded [[Earl Dawson]] as president of the CAHA, on May 29, 1971.{{cite news|title=Kryczka CAHA Head; Addison Honored|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 29, 1971|page=60 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-29-1971-766350/}}{{free access}} The role also made him a director with [[Hockey Canada]] for two years. He hoped to make the CAHA financially independent of both the NHL and the [[Government of Canada]], and become more of an administrative body.{{cite news|title=The Nation|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=September 15, 1971|last=Lynch|first=Charles|page=2 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-15-1971-766428/}}{{free access}} Shortly after becoming president, Kryczka announced a resolution to the [[Memorial Cup]] competition, where the Ontario and Quebec leagues agreed to compete with the Western Canada teams which gave up having extra overage players.{{cite news|title=Memorial Cup issue settled|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=July 24, 1971|page=12|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jul-24-1971-766373/}}{{free access}} As part of the agreement, all three leagues were invited to participate in the meetings to renew the CAHA-NHL contract when it expired in 1972. In June 1971, he announced that the CAHA had rejected an invitation from the IIHF to return to play in the World Championships, since Canada would still not be able to use its professional players.{{cite news|title=briefly...|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=June 7, 1971|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-07-1971-766357/}}{{free access}} Later that year in September, Kryczka stated that the CAHA had not been invited to play in the [[1972 Winter Olympics]] in [[Sapporo]], and accused Ahearne of political grandstanding for saying that Canada could be removed from the IIHF for its refusal to play.{{cite news|title=Olympic Invitation Exists But...|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 4, 1971|last=McNeil|first=Al|page=58 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-04-1971-766400/}}{{free access}} Kryczka met with [[Harold Wright (athlete)|Harold Wright]] of the [[Canadian Olympic Committee|Canadian Olympic Association]] (COA) in September to review the situation, and Wright confirmed that the COA received an invitation to the Winter Olympics on July 28. Wright felt that he decision was in disregard to recreational hockey in Canada, and that the CAHA should send a team, as the Olympics was a different an unrelated tournament, compared to the World Championships.{{cite news|title=Olympians Fire Salvo|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 18, 1971|page=62 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-18-1971-766444/}}{{free access}} The CAHA was urged by the COA to send an amateur team, since the [[U Sports|Canadian Interuniversity Athletics Union]] (CIAU) proposed sending a team in lieu of the CAHA. Despite the discussions, Kryczka was committed to the CAHA's withdrawal from international play, until it could use its best players against the Europeans.{{cite news|title=No Bluff, Says CAHA Leader|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=September 17, 1971|last=Sutton|first=Gerry|page=42|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-17-1971-766442/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Canada To Air Position|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=April 11, 1972|page=49|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-11-1972-773663/}}{{free access}} He stated that Canada would voice its concerns at the next IIHF general meeting in the summer of 1972. He felt that the IIHF should allow professionals in the World Championships similar to [[FIFA]], and reiterated that the CAHA had a good relationship with the NHL, which would release such players for an event. Kryczka remained open to other competitions, which included the [[Izvestia Cup]]. [[File:Dejvice - Hotel Crowne Plaza Prague.jpg|thumb|right|The Hotel International Prague, where negotiations took place for the 1972 Summit Series.]] [[File:Associated Press photo of Kryczka with Ahearne and Staravoitov.png|thumb|right|''[[Associated Press]]'' photo of Kryczka (left), with Bunny Ahearne (centre) and Andrei Starovoytov (right) at the announcement of the agreement to play the series.]] Meanwhile, Kryczka had been collaborating for two years with [[Charles Hay (ice hockey)|Charles Hay]] from Hockey Canada, in attempts to convince the [[Soviet Union]] to play Canada in a hockey series allowing professional players.{{cite news|title=Jim Coleman column|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|last=Coleman|first=Jim|author-link=Jim Coleman (journalist)|date=April 19, 1972|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-19-1972-773688/}}{{free access}}''Houston & Shoalts (1993)'', pp. 76–77 In February 1972, the [[Global Affairs Canada|Canadian Bureau of Public Affairs]] empowered Kryczka, Hay and [[Lou Lefaive]] from [[Sport Canada]], to oversee diplomatic efforts to return Canada to international ice hockey, and gave them needed assistance from [[List of diplomatic missions of Canada|Canadian embassies]] in Europe, and specifically the [[Embassy of Canada in Moscow]].''Macintosh & Hawes (1994)'', p. 32 Other notable Canadians involved in the process included [[Gordon Juckes]] from the CAHA, [[Doug Fisher (politician)|Doug Fisher]] and Allan Scott from Hockey Canada, [[Robert Ford (poet)|Robert Ford]] the Canadian ambassador in Moscow, and translator [[Aggie Kukulowicz]] who worked at [[Air Canada]] in Moscow. The negotiations for a Canada-Soviet series were finalized at the [[Hotel International Prague]] during the [[1972 World Ice Hockey Championships]]. Kryczka was chosen as the lead negotiator of behalf of the Canadian delegation, due to his legal background. He also went into the negotiations with an understanding of the [[Russian language]], but never revealed this to the Soviets.''McKinley, Michael (2014)'', p. 168 As a child, his neighbours were Russian immigrants who never spoke to him in English.{{cite web|title=Man who helped set up games is erased from tournament lore|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/man-who-helped-set-up-games-is-erased-from-tournament-lore/article25305354/|last=Maki|first=Allan|date=2002-09-20|website=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2018-07-13}} After each day of negotiating, he informed Hay of what the Soviets had said to each other. Kryczka later gave an interview to journalist [[Jim Coleman (journalist)|Jim Coleman]], and said that the Soviets had previously decided they could defeat any NHL team, and drew out negotiations to get more concessions on the rules of play.''Houston & Shoalts (1993)'', p. 206 The final agreement negotiated by Kryczka stipulated that Soviet players were to be paid {{CAD|5,000|link=yes}} per game in Canada, and Canadian players were to be paid [[Soviet ruble|SUR]]5,000 per game in [[Moscow]]. It also stipulated the choice of referees was acceptable to both parties. It was signed on April 18, 1972, and agreed to an eight-game series where both [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Team Canada]] and the [[Soviet Union national ice hockey team|Soviet Team]] were allowed unrestricted rosters which included professionals.{{cite news|title=Canada May Rejoin World Hockey|newspaper=European Stars and Stripes|location=Darmstadt, Hesse|date=April 20, 1972|page=21|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-20-1972-773682/}}{{free access}} The two-page document had no official seal or letterhead, but included the signatures of Kryczka, [[Andrey Starovoytov]] as the general secretary of the [[Ice Hockey Federation of Russia|Soviet Union Ice Hockey Federation]], and the approvals of Ahearne as the president of the IIHF, and former CAHA president [[Fred Page]] as the vice-president of the IIHF. Kryczka and Starovoytov announced the agreement later the same day, but Kryczka did not promise that Canada return to the playing at the World Championships.{{cite news|title=It's official, and no pros barred |newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=April 19, 1972|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-19-1972-773675/}}{{free access}} After the successful negotiations with the Soviets, he intended to table a similar proposal for the World Ice Hockey Championships at the next summer congress of the IIHF.{{cite news|title=Kryczka will ask approval|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=June 2, 1972|page=5|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-02-1972-773594/}}{{free access}} [[United Press International]] reported that upcoming Soviet series likely indicated Canada's return to international play, and the IIHF would likely vote in favour of Canada's proposal to include professionals. Kryczka was also encouraged by feedback from IIHF vice-president Page, who was keeping the CAHA informed of international matters, and was also a CAHA director-at-large.{{cite news|title=MJHL Fares Well At CAHA Meeting|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba |date=September 27, 1971|page=45|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-27-1971-766458/}}{{free access}} ===Second year=== Kryczka began his second year as president by speaking to delegates at the 1972 general meeting of the CAHA. He warned of a government report which recommended a paid commissioner to run and oversee amateur hockey in Canada. He felt that would take away the incentive for parents to volunteer in amateur hockey, and kill programs at the grass roots levels of hockey.{{cite news|title=Gov't watching the CAHA|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 23, 1972|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-23-1972-773728/}}{{free access}} The meeting saw the CAHA vote down a rule amendment that would have allowed [[Karen Koch]] to play on a men's team, and Kryczka announced that the CAHA would study its organizational structure, and would be prepared to include female teams and leagues in the future.{{cite news|title=No, Karen can't play with boys|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 25, 1972|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-25-1972-773738/}}{{free access}} Also at the meeting, the AAHA gave notice of resignation from the CAHA, due to differences arising from the CAHA-NHL agreement. The AAHA felt that the CAHA should charge registration fees to player for its administration fees, rather than be bound by the NHL and rely on it for income.{{cite news|title=Alberta says goodbye CAHA|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=May 26, 1972|page=26|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-26-1972-773734/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Albertans Abandon CAHA Ship|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|last=Slivitt|first=Dan|date=May 26, 1972|page=45|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-26-1972-773740/}}{{free access}} Kryczka remained confident that an Alberta branch could be reformed, and operate with the CAHA. He announced in August 1972, that the AAHA rejoined the CAHA after working out their differences.{{cite news|title=briefly...|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=August 17, 1972|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-aug-17-1972-773579/}}{{free access}} [[File:Mamaia Beach (September 2013).JPG|thumb|right|The 1972 summer congress of the IIHF was held in the Romanian [[Black Sea]] resort district of Mamaia, in [[Constanța]].]] Kryczka went to the 1972 summer congress of the IIHF in [[Mamaia]], [[Romania]], to make his proposal for professionals at the World Championships, and was also expecting a North American delegate to replace Ahearne as IIHF president.{{cite news|title=Sports Core|newspaper=Dauphin Herald|location=Dauphin, Manitoba|last=Ferguson|first=Bob|date=August 23, 1972|page=5 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-aug-23-1972-773573/}}{{free access}} The president's position had alternated every three years between Europe and North America, as part of the agreement for the CAHA and the [[USA Hockey|Amateur Hockey Association of the United States]] (AHAUS) to join the IIHF in 1947. Kryczka had been a vocal opponent of IIHF president Ahearne, and criticized Ahearne's meetings as non-parliamentary, and not following acceptable procedures.{{cite news|title=Kryczka criticizes the IIHF|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=May 24, 1972|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-24-1972-773730/}}{{free access}} The North America delegation made Page its unanimous nominee, but instead of Page being acclaimed president, Ahearne declared a vote must take place, and the Europeans disapproved of the nomination. Kryczka was subsequently nominated by the United States, but he declined the position feeling he wasn't experienced enough. After a brief recess and then CAHA secretary Juckes also being voted down, Ahearne was reelected in lieu of an acceptable North American candidate. The roster for the Canada-Soviet series was chosen in August, by a committee composed of members from the CAHA, Hockey Canada, the NHL, and the [[National Hockey League Players' Association]] (NHLPA).{{cite news|title=Best professionals may get a shot at Russians|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|last=McNeil|first=Al|date=April 20, 1972|page=6 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-20-1972-773721/}}{{free access}} Kryczka was disappointed that players from the [[World Hockey Association]] (WHA) were excluded from the series since he felt the team should be open all Canadians regardless of which professional league they played for, but he ultimately accepted the decision.{{cite news|title=Four still excluded from national team|newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=August 3, 1972|page=5 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-aug-03-1972-773587/}}{{free access}} The CAHA scheduled additional exhibition games for the Canadian team while in Europe playing the Soviets, that caused Kryczka and Ahearne to disagree over the television rights of a game against [[Czechoslovakia men's national ice hockey team|Czechoslovakia]], when the CAHA refused to pay royalties to the IIHF which threatened to not sanction the game.{{cite news|title=Attempt at "blackmail" unsuccessful|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=September 26, 1972|page=7|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-26-1972-773551/}}{{free access}} [[File:Luzhniki-sports-palace.jpg|thumb|right|The final four games of the Canada-Soviet series were played at the [[Luzhniki Palace of Sports|Palace of Sports of the Central Lenin Stadium]] in Moscow.]] The Canada-Soviet series began September 2, 1972, and Canadians believed they would easily defeat the Soviets.{{cite web|url=http://www.historyisnowmagazine.com/blog/2014/2/26/when-the-cold-war-became-hot-the-summit-series-between-the-ussr-and-canada#.Wxdf4pxE00M=|title=When the Cold War became Hot – The Summit Series between the USSR and Canada|last=Struth |first=Matthew|date=2014-02-26|website=History is Now Magazine|access-date=2018-07-15}} Instead, after seven games it was tied with 3 wins each and a draw. The Canadians and Soviets disagreed over who should referee the final eighth match. Kryczka was against having the West German officials [[Josef Kompalla]] and [[Franz Baader (ice hockey)|Franz Baader]] referee the game, and demanded to have [[Ove Dahlberg]] of Sweden, and [[Rudy Batja]] of Czechoslovakia.{{cite news|title=Question of Officials Brings Out New Soviet-Canada Ice Dispute|newspaper=Fort Walton Beach Playground Daily News|location=Fort Walton Beach, Florida|date=September 28, 1972|page=13|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-28-1972-773537/}}{{free access}}{{cite web|url=http://nitzyshockeyden.blogspot.com/2012/09/summit-series-72-josef-kompalla-in-his.html?m=1|title=Summit Series '72, Josef Kompalla in his own words|date=2012-09-27|website=Nitzy's Hockey Den|access-date=2018-07-15}} A compromise was reached that included Kompalla and Batja as referees for the eighth game, and in the pregame ceremony Kryczka and [[Alan Eagleson]] presented the Soviet hosts with a [[totem pole]] as a gift from Canada.{{cite news|title=Gimme a M, gimme an A...|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=October 23, 1976|last=Davidson|first=Bill|page=6 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-23-1976-765739/}}{{free access}} Canada went on to win the final game by a 6–5 score, and won the series 4 games to three, with a draw. Kryczka received little credit at the time for his role in the series and was overshadowed by Eagleson, with whom he shared a mutual dislike. Eagleson was attending the World Championships and was not part of the negotiations, but he was the first person to phone Canada from Prague, and take credit for the event by reporting the agreement.''Macintosh & Hawes (1994)'', p. 33 Journalist Remy Greer argued that, "if it wasn’t for the negotiating prowess of Kryczka, the series might never have happened". Eagleson felt that series was made by the NHL players, and gave no thanks to others involved.{{cite web|url=http://o.canada.com/news/eagleson-to-stand-in-shadows-on-anniversary-of-summit-series-triumph|title=Eagleson to stand in shadows on anniversary of Summit Series triumph|last=Fisher|first=Matthew|date=2012-08-31 |website=Canada.com|access-date=2018-07-17}} He felt that Kryczka only helped with the totem pole, and nothing else. Kryczka's wife later said that she needed to sit between them at each game, as they were both "loud-mouthed lawyers" with a "hate-hate relationship". The Canada-Soviet series later became known as the [[Summit Series]], and fostered a source of national pride as a significant historical event.''Henderson & Prime (2011)'', p. 106 Kryczka said that Canadian amateur hockey gained from the series because the CAHA earned $100,000 as its share of the profits, and it would be probable to see another similar professional event due to public demand.{{cite news|title=Future series likely|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=October 4, 1972|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-04-1972-773525/}}{{free access}} He also speculated that the success of the CAHA in negotiating the series, may render the rival Hockey Canada structure obsolete. He was open to more tournaments and games which followed IIHF statutes, and condemned reports that the NHL and the NHLPA were trying to negotiate international games on their own for the sake of keeping profits to themselves, instead of following proper international procedures.{{cite news|title=CAHA Won't Play Dead Over Proposed Series|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=November 9, 1972|page=49|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-nov-09-1972-773496/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Sully Says|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|last=Sullivan|first=Pat|date=November 15, 1972|page=15|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-nov-15-1972-773484/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=CAHA won't bow out|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=December 12, 1972|last=Sutton|first=Gerry|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-dec-12-1972-773473/}}{{free access}} He felt that the CAHA deserved its credit for developing the international game, and opening the door for the NHL to play the Soviets. He said that European clubs were interested in playing, as long as sanctioning went through the IIHF, the CAHA or AHAUS. Canada later played the Soviets again in the [[1974 Summit Series]], which led to the establishment of the [[Canada Cup]] in 1976, and the subsequent return of Team Canada to the World Championships in 1977. After the 1972 series, Kryczka gave a directive to the minor ice hockey council of the CAHA to find ways to improve its youth development system, and catch up to the Soviet system. He looked towards junior hockey as the next big stage for international hockey to be played at the [[IIHF World U20 Championship]] being planned in 1974, and said that Canada and the USA had been collaborating on a [[1975 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|planned 1975 event]].{{cite news|title=CAHA Leader Lauds Junior Tournament|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=December 13, 1972|last=Svoboda|first=Chuck|page=47|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-dec-13-1972-773441/}}{{free access}} He also said that at the junior age level, there would be no concerns over who is or is not a professional player, and that the CAHA agreed to send the reigning Memorial Cup champion to represent Canada at the events. Kryczka announced in January 1973, that he would not seek reelection as CAHA president.{{cite news |title=briefly...|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=January 23, 1973|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jan-23-1973-772053/}}{{free access}} Kryczka's remaining four months as president were occupied by dealing with the WHA competing for junior-aged players, and threatening the CAHA's existing draft and development agreement with the NHL. Kryczka had previously sent a letter to WHA president [[Gary Davidson]], requesting the league honour the age at which players become professionals, as agreed with the NHL.{{cite news|title=CAHA Urges WHA To Follow Rules|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=February 3, 1972|page=50|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-03-1972-773017/}}{{free access}} On February 15, 1973, the WHA permitted its teams one month to negotiate and sign any junior, college, or non-professional of amateur draft age, which Kryczka called disruptive to junior hockey. He warned CAHA teams that any player which signed a professional contract would be ruled ineligible to continue playing in the CAHA.{{cite news|title="Open Signing Period" Announced by WHA Head|newspaper=Colorado Springs Gazette|location=Colorado Springs, Colorado|date=February 10, 1973|page=30 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-10-1973-772047/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=WHA sets sights on 'juniors'|newspaper=Journal News|location=Hamilton, Ohio|date=February 10, 1973|page=12 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-10-1973-772015/}}{{free access}} Kryczka and Juckes set up a meeting on February 23, 1973, between the CAHA, each of its three leagues, and the WHA to the discuss attempted signings of junior players without paying development fees.{{cite news|title=Juniors topic of discussion |newspaper=Medicine Hat News|location=Medicine Hat, Alberta|date=February 8, 1973|page=4|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-08-1973-772038/}}{{free access}} When the [[Houston Aeros (WHA)|Houston Aeros]] signed underage players [[Marty Howe]] and [[Mark Howe]] to professional contracts, Kryczka stated that the WHA was continuing to undermine the junior hockey system in Canada.{{cite news|title=Reaction:CAHA is upset|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=June 6, 1973|last=MacLaine|first=Ian|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-06-1973-770312/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Time Out|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=June 7, 1973|last=Smith|first=Maurice|page=53|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-07-1973-770309/}}{{free access}} In his final speech as president of the CAHA at the 1973 general meeting, he expressed his disappointment in the negotiations being broken off by WHA which claimed development fees being too high. He felt that the WHA was trying to break apart unity by attempting to deal directly with the WCHL instead of the CAHA, and he also discounted rumors that the [[Saskatchewan Hockey Association|Saskatchewan Amateur Hockey Association]] wanted to break away from the CAHA.{{cite news|title=Smart move by CAHA|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 22, 1973|page=7 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-22-1973-771677/}}{{free access}}{{cite news|title=Kryczka Bombards WHA Bid to WCHL|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 22, 1973|last=Johnston|first=Lloyd|page=62|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-22-1973-771669/}}{{free access}} ==Later life== [[File:Joe Kryczka swearing-in as a judge.jpg|thumb|right|Joe Kryczka (right) being sworn-in as a Justice of Court of Queens Bench of Alberta, by W. R. Sinclair (left) at Calgary in July 1980.{{cite web|url=https://albertaonrecord.ca/is-las-72-g-19|title=The swearing-in of Joseph J. Kryczka|date=2013-03-16|website=Alberta On Record|access-date=2018-11-04}}]] Kryczka was succeeded as president of the CAHA by [[Jack Devine (ice hockey)|Jack Devine]], on May 25, 1973 at the annual meeting.{{cite news|title=Devine New CAHA Boss|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 25, 1973|page=52|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-25-1973-771665/}}{{free access}} After his term as president, Kryczka was appointed chairman of the CAHA rules committee, and was responsible for enforcing discipline. He fined the [[Humboldt Broncos]] management $500, for refusing to play game six of the [[1973 Centennial Cup]] playoffs.{{cite news|title=briefly...|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=June 16, 1973|page=9|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jun-16-1973-770311/}}{{free access}} At the 1974 general meeting, the rules committee aimed to reduce eye injuries and obscenities directed at referees, and empowered the officials to enforce the appropriate rules more strictly.{{cite news|title=International junior tourney at Keystone?|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=May 21, 1974|page=13|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-21-1974-766049/}}{{free access}} At the 1975 general meeting, the rules committee dealt with the increase of violence in hockey, recommended more severe penalties for cross-checking and high-sticking above the shoulders, raised the punishment for abuse of officials, and suggested game misconducts to deter fighting.{{cite news|title=Amateur Hockey Violence Faces Rules With 'Teeth'|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=May 20, 1975|last=McNeil|first=Al|page=62|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-may-20-1975-766032/}}{{free access}} On July 23, 1974, Kryczka was appointed to be the first commissioner of the newly formed [[Canadian Hockey League|Canadian Major Junior Hockey League]] (CMJHL), effective August 1, 1974.{{cite news|title=Joe Kryczka commissioner|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=July 24, 1974|page=19|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-jul-24-1974-766040/}}{{free access}} The CMJHL was an umbrella organization composed of the [[Western Hockey League]] (WHL), the [[Ontario Hockey League|Ontario Hockey Association Major Junior A division]], and the [[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League]]. WHL president [[Ed Chynoweth]], said that Kryczka was the unanimous choice among the three constituent leagues, and gave Kryczka the task of writing a constitution, and standardizing the playing rules and players' contracts. Kryczka was one of directors for the [[Calgary Cowboys]] team in the WHA.{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1976/04/26/618194/week-of-disgrace-on-the-ice|title=Week of disgrace on the ice|date=1976-04-26|website=Sports Illustrated|access-date=2018-07-14}}{{cite news|title=Cowboys shopping for Calgary control|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=March 24, 1976|page=59|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-mar-24-1976-765756/}}{{free access}} During the [[1975–76 WHA season|1976 WHA playoffs]] versus the [[Quebec Nordiques]], Kryczka felt that the league caved into the demands of Quebec, because the Nordiques threatened to abandon the series after a series of on-ice incidents.{{cite news|title=Calgary fans display their disapproval|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=April 15, 1976|page=21|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-15-1976-765762/}}{{free access}} He agreed with the ultimate decision to continue the series, and avoid further discredit to the WHA.{{cite news|title=Cowboys are up in arms|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=April 15, 1976|page=6|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-apr-15-1976-765759/}}{{free access}} Kryczka stated that Calgary needed to build a replacement for the [[Stampede Corral]], in order to remain competitive in major league hockey. When rumors surfaced that the Cowboys were considering moving to the proposed [[FirstOntario Centre|Copps Coliseum]] to be built in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], he denied that the team wanted to move, and reiterated a commitment to the city.{{cite news|title=Would it be the Hamilton Cowboys?|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=October 9, 1976|page=8|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-oct-09-1976-765744/}}{{free access}} Kryczka was recognized as a [[Queen's Counsel]] in 1975, for accomplishments as a lawyer, and contributions to the community. He was appointed to the [[Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta]] by [[Jean Chrétien]] in July 1980, the then [[Minister of Justice (Canada)|Minister of Justice of Canada]]. Kryczka served as a justice on the Court of Queen's Bench for the remainder of his life. As a lawyer, he acted as legal counsel for the Alberta Hockey Referees Association, when the organization disputed suspensions by the AAHA for referees officiating games in 1978 without wearing helmets.{{cite news|title=Kryczka joins refs' fight|newspaper=Brandon Sun|location=Brandon, Manitoba|date=September 28, 1978|page=11|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-sep-28-1978-765733/}}{{free access}} Kryczka was named the director of legal affairs for Calgary's [[1988 Winter Olympics]] bid in 1979. He worked with the [[Canadian Olympic Committee]], and helped win the first [[Winter Olympic Games]] hosted in Canada. He met with members of the [[International Olympic Committee]], and was confident that the [[1980 Summer Olympics boycott|American-led boycott]] of the [[1980 Summer Olympics]] would not affect the voting for Calgary's bid.{{cite news|title=Boycott shouldn't affect bid|newspaper=Lethbridge Herald|location=Lethbridge, Alberta|date=August 6, 1980|page=37|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-aug-06-1980-765683/}}{{free access}} The [[Soviet Olympic Committee]] told Calgary bid president [[Frank King (ice hockey)|Frank King]], that it would vote for Canada, if Kryczka ran the hockey events. After the Olympics, Kryczka became a director on the Canadian Olympic Development Association. Kryczka was later diagnosed with [[Colorectal cancer|intestinal cancer]]. He died January 11, 1991, at [[Foothills Medical Centre]] in Calgary. He was interred near his parents at St. Mary's Cemetery in Calgary.{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/28606715/justice-joseph_julius-kryczka|title=Justice Joseph Julius “Joe” Kryczka (1935-1991)|website=Find A Grave|access-date=2018-07-16}} ==Family== [[File:Joe and Adam Kryczka hockey photo.png|thumb|right|Joe and brother Adam Kryczka (right) were teammates on the Golden Bears in 1955.]] Kryczka was the second of three sons to Joseph and Maria Kryczka, who immigrated to Canada in 1934 from [[Zabawa, Wieliczka County|Zabawa, Poland]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fantinsfuneralchapel.ca/notices/Ted-Kryczka|title=Obituary for Ted Kryczka|date=2014|website=Fantin's Funeral Chapel|access-date=2018-07-16}} His father worked in the coalfields at [[Crowsnest Pass]]. His eldest brother Ted also played hockey for the Golden Bears, once participated in a [[Chicago Blackhawks]] training camp, and was a town counselor for Coleman from 1961 to 1978. His younger brother Adam was a goaltender on the Golden Bears, and is the namesake of the [[Canada West University Hockey Awards|Adam Kryczka Memorial Trophy]]. Kryczka was married to Marion North during summit series. At the time of his death, he was married to Beverley Kryczka, and was survived by four children, his mother, his older brother Ted, and one granddaughter. His son Patrick married [[Nicole Dunsdon]], a former [[Miss Canada]], and their son Spencer, played hockey for the [[Okotoks Oilers]], and the [[Princeton Tigers men's ice hockey|Princeton Tigers]].{{cite web|url=https://goprincetontigers.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=12720|title=Spencer Kryczka|website=Princeton Athletics|access-date=2018-10-23}} Kryczka's sister-in-law was Alberta politician [[Karen Kryczka]], who was married to his brother Adam.{{cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/international/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/kryczka-karen-pearce-ba-bed-calgary-west|title=Kryczka, Karen Pearce, B.A., B.Ed. (Calgary-West)|last=Thomson|first=Gale|date=2005|website=Encyclopedia.com|access-date=2018-07-26}} His niece [[Kelly Kryczka]] was an Olympic medalist, and the daughter of Adam and Karen.{{cite web|url=http://canadianobits.com/notables/webbbs_config.pl/noframes/read/42|title=Kryczka, Karen - Progressive Conservative MLA, Calgary West|date=2016-09-14|website=Canadianobits.com|access-date=2018-07-26}} His family kept souvenirs from the Summit Series, including the original two-page document signed in Prague, which had been stored in a safe at his law office. ==Honours== Kryczka was named the 1972 [[Air Canada]] Amateur Sports Executive of the Year.{{cite news|title=Finalists Chosen|newspaper=Winnipeg Free Press|location=Winnipeg, Manitoba|date=December 20, 1973|page=48 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-dec-20-1973-770306/}}{{free access}} As part of its awards program, Air Canada donated a block of 20 air passes to the CAHA on behalf of Kryczka.{{cite news|title=Sports Core|newspaper=Dauphin Herald|location=Dauphin, Manitoba|date=February 7, 1973|last=Ferguson|first=Bob|page=11 |url=https://newspaperarchive.com/sports-clipping-feb-07-1973-772034/}}{{free access}} He received a special achievement award in hockey from the Calgary Booster Club in 1972,''Calgary Booster Club (1986)'', p. 7 and was made an honorary life member of the club in 1982.''Calgary Booster Club (1986)'', p. 1 Kryczka was inducted as a builder into the both the [[Alberta Sports Hall of Fame and Museum|Alberta Sports Hall of Fame]], and [[Canada's Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1990. Other honours include being made a life member of the CAHA,{{cite web|url=https://www.hockeycanada.ca/en-ca/corporate/contact/board-of-directors|title=Board of Directors|website=Hockey Canada|access-date=2018-11-06}} a life member of Hockey Alberta,{{cite web|url=https://www.hockeyalberta.ca/about-hockey-alberta/board-directors/|title=2016-2017 Board of Directors|website=Hockey Alberta|access-date=2018-07-14}} and a life director of the Calgary Olympic Development Association. He is also the namesake of the Joe Kryczka Arena, at the [[Southland Leisure Centre]] in Calgary.{{cite web|url=https://www.hockeycalgary.ca/arena/JOE|title=Arenas−Joe Kryczka (JOE)|website=Hockey Calgary|access-date=2018-07-14}} ==References== '''General''' {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last1=Henderson|first1=Paul|author-link1=Paul Henderson|last2=Prime|first2=Jim|title=How hockey explains Canada: the sport that defines a country|publisher=Triumph Books|location=Chicago, Illinois|isbn=978-1-60078-575-7|year=2011}} *{{cite book|last1=Macintosh|first1=Donald|last2=Hawes|first2=Michael|title=Sport and Canadian Diplomacy|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|date=1994|location=Montreal & Kingston|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G_TwFYjUfssC&pg=PA32|isbn=0-7735-1161-X}} *{{cite book|last=Houston|first=William|last2=Shoalts|first2=David|title=Eagleson: The Fall of a Hockey Czar|publisher=McGraw-Hill Ryerson Ltd.|date=1993|location=Whitby, Ontario|isbn=0-07-551706-X}} *{{cite book|last=Mardson|first=Austin & Ernest|title=Alberta's Judicial Leadership|publisher=Golden Meteorite Press|date=2011|location=Edmonton, Alberta|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g61RAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA102|isbn=978-1-897472-32-3}} *{{cite book|last=McKinley|first=Michael|title=It's Our Game: Celebrating 100 Years Of Hockey Canada|publisher=Viking|date=2014|location=Toronto, Ontario|isbn=978-0-670-06817-3}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.calgaryboosterclub.com/archives/sportsman-of-the-year-dinner-programs/1986.pdf|title=31st Annual Sportsmen's Dinner|date=1986|website=Calgary Booster Club|access-date=2018-07-15}} {{refend}} '''Specific''' {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kryczka, Joe}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:1972 Summit Series]] [[Category:1988 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Joe Louis Arena | nickname = The Joe | logo_image = [[File:Joe Louis Arena.svg]] | image = [[File:Detroit December 2015 59 (Joe Louis Arena).jpg|270px]] | address = 19 [[Steve Yzerman]] Drive | location = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | coordinates = {{Coord|42|19|31|N|83|3|5|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = May 16, 1977{{cite news |title=Begin Work on Stadium|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YxEvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kdwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1553,4758020&dq=en|newspaper=The Ludington Daily News|date=May 17, 1977|accessdate=December 8, 2012}} | opened = December 12, 1979 | closed = July 30, 2017 | demolished = | owner = [[Detroit|City of Detroit]] | operator = [[Olympia Entertainment]] | surface = | construction_cost = US$57 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|57000000|1979}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[SmithGroupJJR]] | project manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Barton Malow{{cite web |title=JLA Construction|url=http://3.cdn.nhle.com/redwings/images/upload/2011/10/JLA_construction.jpg|publisher=Detroit Red Wings|date=October 1, 2011|accessdate=February 8, 2013}} | tenants = [[Detroit Red Wings]] ([[National Hockey League|NHL]]) (1979–2017)
[[Detroit Pistons]] ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]]) (1985)
[[Detroit Drive]] ([[Arena Football League|AFL]]) (1988–1993)
[[Detroit Turbos]] ([[National Lacrosse League|MILL]]) (1989–1994)
[[Detroit Compuware Ambassadors]] ([[Ontario Hockey League|OHL]]) (1991–92)
[[Detroit Junior Red Wings]] (OHL) (1992–1995)
[[Detroit Rockers]] ([[National Professional Soccer League (1984–2001)|NPSL]]) (1996–2000) | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]:
19,275 (1979–1989)
19,875 (1989–1996)
19,983 (1996–2000)
19,995 (2000–2001)
20,058 (2001–2003)
20,066 (2003–2014)
20,027 (2014–2017)
[[Basketball]]: 20,153
Concerts: 21,666{{cite web|title=Arena Info: General Information|url=http://redwings.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=43887|publisher=The Detroit Red Wings|accessdate=December 8, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101013629/http://redwings.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=43887|archivedate=November 1, 2012|df=}} }} [[File:Joe-Louis-Arena.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Inside Joe Louis Arena.]] [[File:Retired numbers at Joe Louis Arena.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The retired numbers of former Detroit Red Wings players displayed at Joe Louis Arena.]] [[File:JoeLouisArenaPanorama.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Panorama of Joe Louis Arena in April 2008.]] [[File:Hoops in Hockeytown.jpg|thumb|rught|250px|The Detroit Shock practice at Joe Louis Arena before Game 5 of the 2006 WNBA Finals.]] '''Joe Louis Arena''' is a defunct multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]. Completed in 1979 at a cost of $57 million as a replacement for the [[Detroit Olympia]], it sits adjacent to [[Cobo Center]] on the bank of the [[Detroit River]] and is accessible by the [[Joe Louis Arena station]] on the [[Detroit People Mover]]. The venue is named after former heavyweight champion [[boxer]] [[Joe Louis]], who grew up in Detroit. It was the home of the [[Detroit Red Wings]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the second oldest NHL venue after [[Madison Square Garden]] until the start of the [[2017–18 NHL season]]. Joe Louis Arena is owned by the city of Detroit, and operated by [[Olympia Entertainment]], a subsidiary of team owner [[Ilitch Holdings]].{{cite web |url=http://www.olympiaentertainment.com/about-olympia-entertainment|title=About Olympia Entertainment|accessdate=July 2, 2017}} In April 2017, the Red Wings hosted their final game at Joe Louis Arena; the venue was succeeded by the new [[Little Caesars Arena]], in [[Midtown Detroit]], beginning with the 2017–18 season. Joe Louis Arena will be demolished, and its site slated for redevelopment. The arena closed on July 30, 2017. Demolition was scheduled to begin in September 2017, but Olympia renewed the lease of the arena with the city and are using it as storage and offices until November 2017. Olympia Entertainment moved out in November 2017, and demolition is planned to begin sometime in 2019.https://www.freep.com/story/money/business/2018/02/03/demolition-detroit-joe-louis-arena/1088694001/ ==History== Joe Louis Arena replaced the [[Olympia Stadium]], where the [[Detroit Red Wings]] had played since 1927. The neighborhood around the Olympia had gradually deteriorated, especially after the [[1967 Detroit riot]]. After two murders near the Olympia, Red Wings owner [[Bruce Norris (ice hockey)|Bruce Norris]] seriously considered moving to a proposed arena in suburban [[Pontiac, Michigan|Pontiac]]. However, the city of Detroit countered with a proposal for a new riverfront arena at one-third of the rent Pontiac was offering. The package also gave the Red Wings operational control of the arena, nearby [[Cobo Arena]] and nearby lots. The arena hosted its first event on December 12, 1979: a college basketball game between the [[1979–80 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team|University of Michigan]] and the [[Detroit Titans men's basketball|University of Detroit]].{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} The Red Wings played their first game at Joe Louis Arena on December 27, 1979, hosting the [[St. Louis Blues]]. The game ended in a 3-2 loss for the Red Wings.{{cite news |title=Red Wings Celebrate 30th Anniversary of Joe Louis Arena|first=Ansar|last=Khan|url=http://www.mlive.com/redwings/index.ssf/2009/12/red_wings_celebrate_30th_anniv.html|work=Michigan Live|date=December 26, 2009|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} The Red Wings first win at the arena came on December 30, 1979, where they defeated the [[New York Islanders]] 4-2. {{fact|date=November 2018}} Later that first season it hosted the 32nd [[National Hockey League All-Star Game|NHL All-Star Game]] on February 5, 1980,{{cite web |title=NHL All-Star Game Summaries/Results by Year|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/page.htm?id=29166|publisher=National Hockey League|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} which was played before a then-NHL record crowd of 21,002. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the [[1987 NHL Entry Draft]], which marked the first NHL Entry Draft to be held in the United States. In 1980, the arena hosted the [[1980 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]] that nominated [[Ronald Reagan]] as the Republican candidate for [[President of the United States]]. [[File:New scoreboard.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The electronic scoreboard at Joe Louis Arena, during a game between the [[Detroit Red Wings]] and the [[Los Angeles Kings]] on March 9, 2007]] In 1990, color matrix boards were installed on the scoreboard; these were replaced by four Sony [[JumboTron]] video walls three years later, when the matrix boards were placed in the corners of the fascia. In 2006, LED video screens replaced the JumboTrons. The screens debuted November 22, 2006, when the Red Wings played the [[Vancouver Canucks]]. That same day, the arena's West Entrance was named the "[[Gordie Howe]] Entrance" in honor of the legendary Red Wing player, and a bronze statue of Howe was placed inside the entrance. Joe Louis Arena houses 86 premium suites.{{cite web |url=http://hockey.ballparks.com/NHL/DetroitRedWings/index.htm|title=Joe Louis Arena|work=Ballparks.com|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} In 2008, the arena introduced the Comerica Bank Legend's Club, a 181-person private seating location in the arena's southeast corner.{{cite news |title=Competitive Spirit Makes Mike Ilitch Perfect Fit for Pistons|first=Bob|last=Wojnowski|url=http://detnews.com/article/20100810/OPINION03/8100328/Competitive-spirit-makes-Mike-Ilitch-perfect-fit-for-Pistons|newspaper=[[The Detroit News]]|date=August 10, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} === Replacement === {{main|Little Caesars Arena}} On July 20, 2014, following the July 2013 approval of a $650 million project to build a new sports and entertainment district in Downtown Detroit,{{cite news |title=$650 Million Detroit Red Wings Arena Project Clears Another Public Financing Hurdle|first=David|last=Muller|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/detroit/index.ssf/2013/07/650_million_detroit_red_wings.html|work=[[Booth Newspapers|MLive]]|date=July 24, 2013|accessdate=July 24, 2013}}{{cite web |title=DDA, Red Wings Unveil $650 Million Arena and Entertainment Complex|first=Bill|last=Shea|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20130619/NEWS/130619810/dda-red-wings-unveil-650-million-arena-and-entertainment-complex#|work=Crain's Detroit Business|date=June 19, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2013}} Christopher Ilitch unveiled designs for a [[Little Caesars Arena|new arena]] near [[Comerica Park]] and [[Ford Field]] which was completed in 2017 and succeeded Joe Louis Arena as the home of the Red Wings.{{cite web|title=Detroit Rink City: Ilitches' grand plan to supersize the entertainment district|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20140720/NEWS03/140719845/detroit-rink-city-ilitches-grand-plan-to-supersize-the|website=Crain's Detroit Business|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} On October 16, 2014, lawyers involved in the ongoing [[Detroit bankruptcy]] case disclosed [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan|in court]] that after demolition (which will be paid for by the city and state), the land on which the arena stands, along with an adjacent parking lot, will be transferred to the [[Financial Guaranty Insurance Company]] (FGIC), a bond insurer with a $1 billion claim against the city.{{cite news|title=Detroit bankruptcy deal: Joe Louis Arena site to go to creditor for hotel development|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/detroit/index.ssf/2014/10/detroit_bankruptcy_deal_joe_lo.html|accessdate=17 October 2014|work=MILive.com|date=16 October 2014}} The Red Wings' final game at Joe Louis Arena was played on April 9, 2017 against the [[New Jersey Devils]]. The Red Wings won 4–1, the final goal in the arena's history coming from Red Wing [[Riley Sheahan]]. It was the second of two he scored, which were also the only goals he scored at all during the 2016–17 season.{{cite web|title=Watch Red Wings' Riley Sheahan end 79-game drought with first goal|url=http://www.mlive.com/redwings/index.ssf/2017/04/watch_red_wings_riley_sheahan.html|website=MLive|accessdate=31 May 2017}}{{cite web|title=What slump? Riley Sheahan scores two goals in Joe Louis Arena finale|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nhl/red-wings/2017/04/09/red-wings-riley-sheahan-goal/100266430/|website=Detroit Free Press|accessdate=31 May 2017}} The last ticketed event held at The Joe was a [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] Live Event, held on July 29, 2017. The arena will be demolished and replaced with new development at the site in 2019. ==Other tenants and events== In 1995, the [[Detroit Junior Red Wings]] won the [[Ontario Hockey League]]'s [[J. Ross Robertson Cup]], defeating the [[Guelph Storm]]. Joe Louis Arena hosted college hockey events as part of [[College Hockey at The Joe]], the [[Great Lakes Invitational]], and the [[Big Ten Conference]] hockey tournament in 2015 and 2017.{{cite news |title=New Detroit Arena Will Be in Mix to Host Many Events|first=George|last=Sipple|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/nhl/red-wings/2014/09/24/detroit-red-wings-arena/16155149/|newspaper=Detroit Free Press|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=November 18, 2014}} The [[Detroit Pistons]] of the NBA used the arena for Game 5 of [[1984 NBA Playoffs#(4) Detroit Pistons vs. (5) New York Knicks|their 1984 playoff series]] against the [[New York Knicks]] when the [[Pontiac Silverdome]] was unavailable due to a scheduling conflict. In the game, Pistons star [[Isiah Thomas]] scored 16 points in the final 1:34 of regulation to send the game into overtime before the Pistons lost. The Pistons were forced to return to Joe Louis Arena for 15 games during the 1984–85 season, after the roof of the Silverdome collapsed during a snowstorm. The National Hockey League's [[Detroit Red Wings]] hosted the [[Stanley Cup Finals]] at the arena six times (1995, 1997, 1998, 2002, 2008, and 2009), and won two of their Stanley Cup championships at Joe Louis Arena in 1997 and 2002. The 1998 Stanley Cup championship was won in Washington, D.C.'s [[MCI Center]] and the 2008 championship was won in Pittsburgh's [[Mellon Arena]]. The Red Wings lost in the Finals to New Jersey in 1995 at the [[Meadowlands Arena]] and lost on home ice in the 2009 Stanley Cup Finals to Pittsburgh. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the decisive Game 5 of the [[2006 WNBA Finals]] between the [[Sacramento Monarchs]] and [[Detroit Shock]] on September 9, due to [[The Palace of Auburn Hills]] (the Shock's usual home arena) being used for a [[Mariah Carey]] concert on the same day. The Shock won the game 80–75 to clinch the championship. Former [[Arena Football League]] team the [[Detroit Drive]] also had success during their time at the arena, playing in six consecutive ArenaBowls from 1988 to 1993 and winning four of them. Four of the games ([[ArenaBowl III]], [[ArenaBowl IV]], [[ArenaBowl V]] and [[ArenaBowl VII]]) were played in Joe Louis Arena. Joe Louis Arena was the site of the [[2013 Skate America|2013 edition]] of the [[Skate America]] figure skating competition. In addition, Joe Louis Arena hosted the [[1994 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]], best known for the pre-competition attack on [[Nancy Kerrigan]] by associates of [[Tonya Harding]]. It was announced on May 7, 2015, that the [[Horizon League Men's Basketball Tournament]] would be held in Detroit beginning in 2016 under a five-year deal; the 2016 and 2017 tournaments were held at Joe Louis Arena.{{cite web|title=Moving Horizon League tourney to Detroit is all about branding|url=http://www.detroitnews.com/story/sports/college/2015/05/07/jla-to-host-horizon-league-basketball-tournament/70957924/|website=Detroit News|publisher=Digital First Media|accessdate=8 May 2015|date=May 7, 2015}} Joe Louis Arena was also a [[concert]] venue. Until the Palace of Auburn Hills was built in 1988, Joe Louis Arena was Michigan's largest indoor arena for concerts. The first concert to take place there occurred on February 17, 1980,{{Cite web|url =http://www.2112.net/powerwindows/tours/800217ticket.jpg|title =February 17th, 1980 Rush ticket stub|date =|access-date =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160415110222/http://www.2112.net/powerwindows/tours/800217ticket.jpg|archivedate =2016-04-15|df =}} in which [[Max Webster]] opened for the Canadian rock group [[Rush (band)|Rush]] To compensate for most of Joe Louis Arena's concert business being moved north following the opening of the Palace, the Red Wings began a tradition of playing a home game on [[New Year's Eve]]. Aside from [[Labor unrest|lockouts]] cancelling part or all of the [[1994–95 NHL lockout|1994–95]], [[2004–05 NHL lockout|2004–05]], and [[2012–13 NHL lockout|2012–13]] seasons, the Red Wings left the New Year's Eve date open in years they were scheduled to participate in the [[NHL Winter Classic]]. For New Year's Eve 2012 and 2013, the [[Zac Brown Band]] held concerts at the Joe. The 2012 date was open due to the planned 2013 Winter Classic that was postponed by lockout until [[2014 NHL Winter Classic|2014]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Metro Detroit}} {{Commons category|Joe Louis Arena}} * [http://www.olympiaentertainment.com/venues/detail/joe-louis-arena Official website] * [https://archive.is/20130110214424/http://www.expotv.com/videos/reviews/21/188/Joe-Louis-Arena/175440 Video review of Joe Louis Arena] * revision.text:
{{About|the Rome, New York arena|other uses|Civic Arena (disambiguation){{!}}Civic Arena}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Kennedy Arena| nickname = | image = | caption = | location = 500 West Embargo Street
Rome, New York 13440| coordinates = {{Coord|43.21966|-75.46363|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Rome| operator = City of Rome| surface = 200' × 85' (ice hockey)| construction_cost= | architect = | former_names = | tenants = Copper City Chiefs (semi-professional hockey team), [[Rome Frenzy]] ([[Federal Hockey League|FHL]]; 2010–2011) }} The '''John F. Kennedy Civic Arena''' (also known as '''Kennedy Arena''') is an indoor [[ice skating]] and [[ice hockey]] arena located in [[Rome, New York]]. The arena was home to the [[Copper City Chiefs]] of the [[North East Hockey League]] during the league's failed 2007–2008 season. The arena would have been home to the [[Eastern Professional Hockey League (2008)|Eastern Professional Hockey League]] franchise, but the team folded before the season. Since 2010, it has been home to the [[Rome Frenzy]] of the [[Federal Hockey League]]. The John F. Kennedy Civic Arena is one of the [[City of Rome]]’s most popular venues. It was originally constructed in 1963, opened in 1964, and renovated in 2008. The arena hosts numerous figure skating and ice hockey events, as well as learn-to-skate programs for youths. It is home to the Rome Free Academy varsity hockey team, which plays its home games at the 1,200-seat facility. The arena is a regional facility, used primarily for ice hockey and figure skating from October through March. The primary users are the Ford Stanwix Hockey Association, a not-for-profit youth hockey organization; Rome Free Academy; Rome Catholic High School; a local figure skating club; various local groups and organizations, and the general public. The arena is located at 500 W. Embargo Street in the City of Rome. It is co-located with the Municipal Pool. Municipal Pool is a community facility, open from June through early September. It includes a standard-size recreational swimming pool, two water play slides, and a bathhouse with restrooms. It meets the recreational swimming needs of west Rome. The arena and pool are served by a large parking lot off of Jay and Embargo Streets with space for more than 150 vehicles. A smaller lot on the arena's west side is used primarily by employees and hockey officials. ==Copper City Chiefs== The Copper City Chiefs semi-professional hockey team was established in 1963 and folded at the end of the 1988 season. The team played in the Kennedy Arena when it opened in 1964. During the 1960s they played in a league of cities in the state of New York. In the 1970s they played in a league of teams from New England states and New York. In the 1980s, the team played against Senior A, Senior B, and Intermediate Level teams from Ontario, Canada. The Rome Copper City Chiefs were organized in 1963 under their original name of the Rome Knights, an unchartered recreational organization which was begun to provide athletic recreation in the form of ice hockey to adults who had played minor professional or college ice hockey. For six years, until 1971, the Knights played ice hockey by invitation; that is, inviting teams from the surrounding area to Rome's John F. Kennedy Arena.Ron Sweeney, interview conducted by Robert Kirchner, Rome, New York, 21 May 1985. The Knights were not part of any formal league at this time, nor were they affiliated with a National Hockey League (NHL) or professional hockey team. However, during their existence many of their rostered players had some minor professional experience. The Knights engaged in strictly invitational hockey games, usually paying expenses of the opposing team so they would play in Rome. This was gradually expanded over the years to include teams from as far away as Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the Canadian province of Ontario. In the middle 1960s, interest in the Knights ice hockey team increased, primarily as an overflow from the [[Clinton Comets]] of the Eastern Hockey League, a professional farm team for the New York Rangers of the NHL. The presence of former Clinton Comets, along with the Knights' physical style of play, stimulated the general population's interest in attending Rome Knights hockey games. In 1971 the Rome Knights changed their name to the Copper City Chiefs. Rome is referred to as the Copper City, after the Revere Manufacturing Plant that once produced copperware in the city through the 1970s. The Rome Copper City Chiefs continued to play invitational games and increased their following in and around central New York. In 1971 the Clinton Comets folded. This brought more professional players to the Chiefs and added to the increased attendance at their games. A new general manager took control of the team and instituted a publicity campaign to further increase game attendance and provide further incentives for local business sponsorship. During the 1972–1973 season, the Chiefs' general manager met with managers of opposing teams, and they decided to form the Northeastern United States Hockey League. This was composed of teams from upstate New York, parts of Massachusetts, and northern New Jersey. League play, coupled with increased advertising and publicity, helped increase attendance, but also required the Chiefs to play in more away games. As added incentive for fans to attend their games, schedules of play were arranged for the 1973-1974 season to give maximum home play to teams that had a traditional adversary relationship. The league was successful and attendance between 1973 and 1975 increased to an overall average of 900 per game. End-of-season league play-offs were standing room only. But involvement in the league, which was never formalized enough to support and enforce the schedules (i.e., no penalty for missed games, forfeitures), also created additional expenses for all the teams. The league folded as teams withdrew due to financial hardships.Rome (New York) ''Daily Sentinel'', 11 February 1974 During their 25 years of existence, supporter participation fluctuated, peaking during 1973-1975. Those seasons showed average game attendances of approximately 900. After the 1975 season, participation gradually declined, culminating in the 1984-1985 season's average attendance of 250.David Adams, interview conducted by Robert Kirchner, Rome, New York, 2 June 1985. ==Renovations== After an almost $3.5 million renovation, Kennedy Arena was officially dedicated on January 30, 2009.[http://www.romenewyork.com/organization.asp?orgid=193 J. F. Kennedy Arena Renovation Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070821024117/http://www.romenewyork.com/organization.asp?orgid=193 |date=2007-08-21 }} The renovation raised the [[seating capacity]] from 800 to 1,200. Other improvements included a longer ice rink; new boards, glass, and safety net; new bleachers across the back end of the arena; four new locker rooms; upgrades to locker rooms; and an enhanced heating and lighting system.http://when-in-rome.com/index.php Improvements were also made to the warming room and concession area, to allow for more and better off-season use of the facility, including usage by teens and seniors. The shell of the building remains relatively unchanged from its original construction in 1963. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.romenewyork.com/organization.asp?orgid=45 Kennedy Arena on RomeNewYork.com] [[Category:Sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Oneida County, New York]] [[Category:Rome, New York]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:1964 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]]
