{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Kaiser Permanente Arena | nickname = | logo_image = Kaiser Permanente Arena logo.jpg | image = Santa Cruz Warriors Military Appreciation Night 2014.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Military Appreciation Night at Kaiser Permanente Arena on April 1, 2014 | location = [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]], [[California]], [[United States]] | broke_ground = September 18, 2012{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/dleague/santacruz/sc_faqs.html|title=NBA Development League: Project FAQs|work=NBA.com|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} | opened = December 23, 2012 | owner = | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]3.5 million{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/warriors/ci_20847317/santa-cruz-warriors-presence-adds-interest-nba-draft|title=Santa Cruz Warriors presence adds interest to NBA draft|author=Julie Jag, Santa Cruz Sentinel|date=June 13, 2012|publisher=|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} | architect = | tenants = [[Santa Cruz Warriors]] ([[NBA G League]]) (2012–present)
[[UC Santa Cruz Banana Slugs]] ([[NCAA Division III|NCAA DIII]]) (2013–present)
[[Santa Cruz Derby Girls]] ([[Women's Flat Track Derby Association|WFTDA]]) | seating_capacity = 2,505 }} '''Kaiser Permanente Arena''' is an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[California]]. It has a seating capacity of 2,505 spectators.[http://www.cityofsantacruz.com/index.aspx?page=1917 City of Santa Cruz : Kaiser Permanente Arena] It hosts the [[Santa Cruz Warriors]] of the [[NBA G League]]. It also is the home of the [[Santa Cruz Derby Girls]] of the [[Women's Flat Track Derby Association]].http://www.santacruzderbygirls.org/press/latest-news/900-2013-new-venue-announced The [[naming rights]] were bought by health care consortium [[Kaiser Permanente]] despite the company—a sponsor of the Warriors' owner, the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[Golden State Warriors]]—not having facilities in Santa Cruz at the time.{{cite web|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/ci_20842270/warriors-unveil-logo-and-arena-sponsor-santa-cruz?source=most_viewed|title=Warriors unveil logo and arena sponsor for Santa Cruz team|publisher=|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} KP has since opened medical facilities in Santa Cruz, Scotts Valley and Watsonville. ==History== A $3.5 million loan by the city of Santa Cruz was given to the Warriors to build their arena, with the 1.5-acre lot being provided by the Santa Cruz Seaside Company, owner of the [[Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk]]. Construction ran for 78 days between September and December 2012, halted just a few times by rain.{{cite web|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/localnews/ci_22244068/ready-go-sc-warriors-arena-passes-inspections-city?source=pkg|title=Ready to go: Santa Cruz Warriors arena passes inspections, city reminds fans about parking for home opener|publisher=|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} The arena was opened on December 23, 2012, with a victory by the Warriors against the [[Bakersfield Jam]].{{cite news|last=May|first=Jacob|title=NBA D-League: Santa Cruz Warriors slam Jam in inaugural home game|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/localnews/ci_22252831/nba-d-league-santa-cruz-warriors-slam-jam|accessdate=December 24, 2012|newspaper=Santa Cruz Sentinel}} By April 2014, Kaiser Permanente Arena had 39 sell-outs out of the 53 Warriors home games. In the meantime, the Warriors reached two D-League finals.{{cite web|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/santacruz/ci_25624995/love-game-bond-between-warrior-city-surprising-success?source=nav|title=Love of the Game: Bond between Warriors, city a surprising success|publisher=|accessdate=January 8, 2016}} The arena has a seating capacity of 2,505.{{cite news |last1=Hayes |first1=Reggie |title=Untitled |work=News-Sentinel |date=May 23, 2015 |location=Fort Wayne, Indiana}} The [[United States men's national basketball team]] hosted their [[FIBA]] [[FIBA Basketball World Cup|World Cup]] qualifying first-round games at Kaiser Permanente Arena on February 23, 2018 against [[Cuba men's national basketball team|Cuba]] and on February 26, 2018 against [[Puerto Rico men's national basketball team|Puerto Rico]].{{cite news |title=Mad Ants' Trey McKinney-Jones added to USA roster |work=News-Sentinel |date=February 8, 2018 |location=Fort Wayne, Indiana}} The arena also serves as the home of [[UC Santa Cruz]] men's and women's basketball games. In November 2017, UC Santa Cruz hosted a [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] basketball tournament at Kaiser Permanente Arena.{{cite news |title=Bearcats Squash Banana Slugs in Overtime, 56-52, at UCSC Thanksgiving Classic |work=US Official News |agency=Willamette University |publisher=Plus Media Solutions |date=November 28, 2017}} ==See also== *[[Citizens Business Bank Arena]] *[[Jenny Craig Pavilion]] *[[McKeon Pavilion]] *[[UCLA Health Training Center]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Use American English|date=January 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} ==External links== *[http://santacruz.gleague.nba.com/news/game-day-information/ Arena Information — Santa Cruz Warriors] via santacruz.gleague.nba.com *[https://arenadigest.com/tag/kaiser-permanente-arena/ Kaiser Permanente Arena] via ArenaDigest.com {{D-League Arenas}} {{coord|36|58|07|N|122|01|25|W|type:landmark_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in California]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:Santa Cruz Warriors]] [[Category:2012 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:Basketball venues in California]] [[Category:Santa Cruz, California]] {{California-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox venue | name = Kenneth M. Robbins Stadium | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = Lancer Stadium (1971–1977, 1980–1994)
Loyalsock Stadium (1978–1979) | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = Pennsylvania#USA | pushpin_relief = yes | pushpin_label = ''KMR Stadium'' | pushpin_map_caption = Location within PA / United States | pushpin_label_position = | location = [[Loyalsock Township, Pennsylvania|Loyalsock Township]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] (near [[Williamsport, Pennsylvania|Williamsport]]) | coordinates = {{Coord|41.2621|-76.9642|type:landmark_region:US-PA|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[Loyalsock Township School District]] | operator = Loyalsock Township School District | surface = * [[Grass]] (1971–2010) * [[Astroturf]] (2011–present) | scoreboard = yes | capacity = 3,500 | record_attendance = | built = | opened = {{start date and age|1971}} | tenants = [[Loyalsock Township High School|Loyalsock Lancers]] (1971–present)
[[Lycoming College|Lycoming Warriors]] (1979, 1982) }} '''Kenneth M. Robbins Stadium''' (formerly '''Lancer Stadium''') is an outdoor multi-purpose [[stadium]] in [[Loyalsock Township, Pennsylvania]] near [[Williamsport, Pennsylvania|Williamsport]] in [[North Central Pennsylvania]]. The stadium currently is home to the Loyalsock Lancers football, boys and girls soccer teams.{{cite web | url = http://pafootballnews.com/15-loyalsock-township-lancers/ | title = Loyalsock Athletics - Kenneth M Robbins Stadium | date = 16 September 2017}} The stadium is owned and operated by the [[Loyalsock Township School District]]. == History== Formerly called Lancer Stadium was opened in 1971. And has been remodeled multiple times in its history. Including new bleachers added in late 1990s, terf added in 2011. The turf was donated after the sports [[dome]] in [[Muncy, Pennsylvania]] collapsed after large amounts of snow on the roof caused the collapse. Originally designed as indoor turf it was transplanted at Kenneth M. Robbins Stadium. In 2017, school board and township members announced plans on replacing the turf in 2018. On December 23, 2017 officials announced the new terf work will begin in March 2018 and be complete by August 1, 2018.{{cn|date=June 2018}} ==Notable events== *1979 and 1982 Lycoming Warriors football teams played home games at the stadium *1999 [[PIAA]] State football quarter-finals[http://findplace.us/Pennsylvania/Williamsport/Kenneth-M-Robbins-Stadium]{{dead link|date=June 2018}} *2001 PIAA State football semi-finals *2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017 PIAA soccer States semi-finals ==See also== * [[Sports in Pennsylvania]] * [[High school football]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Soccer venues in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1971]] [[Category:1971 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} The '''Lobodome''' (officially '''Lobodome de la UAD a Mazatlan''') is a 3,000-seat<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxnoticias.net/noticiaImprimible.php?p=15960 |title=El "Lobo Dome", De Mazatlán, Será Sede De La Cartelera: "Choque De Naciones" |publisher=Boxnoticias.net |date= |accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref> indoor [[arena]] located in [[Mazatlan, Sinaloa]], Mexico.
It is used primarily for basketball, and is home to the Lobos de [[Universidad Autónoma de Durango]]-Mazatlan basketball team. It is also used for [[concerts]], [[boxing]] and [[lucha libre]]. It was one of the original buildings of the UAD's Mazatlan campus which was established in 1999.<ref>[http://prezi.com/ncqczszcchgy/curso-de-induccion-ius-uad-campus-mazatlan/ Curso de induccion IUS UAD Campus Mazatlan at prezi.com]</ref> One of the first events at the arena was a concert by [[Lorena Herrera]], a Mazatlan native. Until the [[Mazatlan International Center]] was built, it was the largest indoor venue in the city. Concert capacity of the Lobodome is around 4,000. Despite its name, the arena's roof is arch-shaped.
The Lobodome was the site of an exhibition basketball game featuring [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] stars on October 8, 2011, during the [[2011 NBA Lockout|NBA Lockout]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mexicotoday.org/article/charlotte-bobcats-forward-eduardo-najera-brings-nba-stars-goodwill-trip-mexico |title=Charlotte Bobcats Forward, Eduardo Najera, Brings NBA Stars on Goodwill Trip to Mexico | Mexico Current News and Mexico Current Events, all the Latest News on Mexico Today |publisher=Mexicotoday.org |date=October 13, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2011}}</ref> In addition to the aforementioned, other national and international stars, including [[Thalía]], [[Gloria Trevi]], [[Paulina Rubio]], [[Los Tigres del Norte]], [[Rocio Durcal]], [[Maribel Guardia]], [[Vicente Fernandez]], [[Pepe Aguilar]], [[Jenni Rivera]], and even [[Air Supply]]<ref>[http://www.hotelplayamazatlan.com/mx/event/air-supply-en-mazatlan/ Air Supply en Mazatlan]</ref> have performed here.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121124033404/http://mazatlan.uad.mx/ Universidad Autónoma de Durango a Mazatlan]
==References== {{reflist}}

Patras''' |- |'''Full name'''||'''Naftathlitiki Enossi Patron''' |- |'''Colours'''||[[blue]], [[white]] |- |'''Founded'''||2006 |- |''''''|Court||'''[[Antonios Pepanos]]'''
aquatic center |- |''''''|Capacity||'''4.000''' |- |'''Sports'''||'''Water polo
Swimming''' |} '''NE Patras''' (NEP), Nautical Union of Patras (Ναυταθλητική Ένωση Πατρών), is a [[water polo]] and [[swimming (sport)|swimming]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thebest.gr/news/index/viewStory/312201 |title=Τα αποτελέσματα της ΝΕΠ στην Περιφερειακή Ημερίδα κολύμβησης - Αθλητισμός - The Best News |publisher=Thebest.gr |date=2015-01-22 |accessdate=2015-02-17}} club situated in [[Patras, Greece]]. == History == [[File:A. Pepanos swimming pool(3).jpg|thumb|220px|[[Antonios Pepanos]] aquatic center, [[Koukouli (Patras)]].]] NEP was founded in 2006 in [[Patras]], [[Western Greece]] with the unification of two nautical clubs of the city: [[Thriamvos Patras]] (founded in 1976) and Poseidon Patras (founded in 1982).[http://www.nep.org.gr/M/ ]{{dead link|date=February 2015}} The club is today participating in the Second Division/A2 Ethniki of the Greek Championships of men and women. NEP has participated in the First Division ([[A1 Greek water polo|A1 Ethniki]]) and the [[A1 Ethniki Women's Water Polo|A1 Ethniki Women's]], reaching in both department the League's '''fourth place'''. In 2010, NEP Women's team reached the [[Women's LEN Trophy]] '''final four''', ending up in the 3rd place.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.gr/node/122321 |title=Πάει φάιναλ φορ η ΝΕΠ |publisher=gazzetta.gr |date= |accessdate=2015-02-17}} ==Honours== *'''Women **'''[[A1 Ethniki Women's Water Polo|A1 Ethniki Women]]''' participation: 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 **'''[[Women's LEN Trophy]]''' participation: 2007, 2008, 2010 *'''Men **'''[[A1 Greek water polo|A1 Ethniki]]''' participation: 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011 **'''[[LEN Euro Cup]]''' participation:{{cite web|url=http://wpagency.eu/index.php?option=news&news_id=87 |title=N.C. Vouliagmenis and N.E. Patras qualify! |publisher=Wpagency.eu |date=2009-11-10 |accessdate=2015-02-17}} 2010 ==Gallery== File:NOP A. Xristopoulos Cup, U12 (4).JPG|NE Patras children's swimming department, 2011. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Waterpolo in Greece}} {{A1 Greek water polo}} [[Category:Water polo clubs in Greece]] [[Category:Sport in Patras]] {{Greece-sport-stub}} {{waterpolo-team-stub}}

[[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2009|2009]] (women's nordic) }} '''Ski jumping''' is a [[winter sport]] in which competitors aim to achieve the longest jump after descending from a specially designed [[ramp]] on their [[ski]]s. Along with jump length, competitor's style and other factors affect the final score. Ski jumping was first contested in Norway in the late 19th century, and later spread through Europe and North America in the early 20th century. Along with [[cross-country skiing]], it constitutes the traditional group of [[Nordic skiing]] disciplines. The [[ski jumping hill|ski jumping venue]], commonly referred to as a ''hill'', consists of the jumping ramp (''in-run''), take-off table, and a landing hill. Each jump is evaluated according to the distance traveled and the style performed. The distance score is related to the [[construction point]] (also known as the ''K-point''), which is a line drawn in the landing area and serves as a "target" for the competitors to reach.{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/sports/olympics/ski-jumping-and-nordic-combined-winter-olympics-spectators-guide|title=Ski Jumping Winter Olympics Spectator’s Guide by Ron Judd (13/12/2009)|publisher=[[The Seattle Times]]|accessdate=18 May 2015}} The score of each judge evaluating the style can reach a maximum of 20 points. The [[ski jumping techniques|jumping technique]] has evolved over the years, from jumps with the parallel skis with both arms pointing forwards, to the "[[ski jumping techniques#V-style|V-style]]", which is widely used today. Ski jumping has been included at the [[Winter Olympics]] since 1924 and at the [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] since 1925. Women's participation in the sport began in the 1990s, while the first women's event at the Olympics has been held in 2014. All major ski jumping competitions are organised by the [[International Ski Federation]]. [[Stefan Kraft]] holds the official record for the [[list of the longest ski jumps|world's longest ski jump]] with {{convert|253.5|m|ft}}, set on the [[ski flying]] hill in [[Vikersundbakken|Vikersund]] in 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2017-03-18/kraft-sets-world-record-in-ski-jumping|title=Kraft Sets World Record in Ski Jumping|accessdate=18 March 2017|date=18 March 2017|publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]]}} Ski jumping can also be performed in the summer on an in-run where the tracks are made from porcelain and the grass on the slope is covered with water-soaked plastic. The highest level summer competition is the [[FIS Ski Jumping Grand Prix]], contested since 1994. {{TOC limit|2}} == History == [[Image:Rye Olaf.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Olaf Rye]]]] Like most of the [[Nordic skiing]] disciplines, the first ski jumping competitions were held in [[Norway]] in the 19th century, although there is evidence of ski jumping in the late 18th century. The recorded origins of the first ski jump trace back to 1808, when [[Olaf Rye]] reached {{convert|9.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}. [[Sondre Norheim]], who is regarded as the "father" of the modern ski jumping, won the first-ever ski jumping competition with prizes, which was held in [[Høydalsmo]] in 1866. The first larger ski jumping competition was held on [[Husebyrennet]] hill in [[Oslo]], Norway, in 1875. Due to its poor infrastructure and the weather conditions, in 1892 the event was moved to [[Holmenkollen]], which is today still one of the main ski jumping events in the season. In the late 19th century, Sondre Norheim and Nordic skier [[Karl Hovelsen]] immigrated to the United States and started developing the sport in that country. In 1924, ski jumping was featured at the [[1924 Winter Olympics]] in [[Chamonix]], France. The sport has been featured at the every Olympics since. Ski jumping was brought to Canada by Norwegian immigrant [[Nels Nelsen]]. Starting with his example in 1915 until the late 1960s, annual ski jumping competitions were held on Mount Revelstoke — the ski hill Nelsen designed — the longest period of any Canadian ski jumping venue. Revelstoke's was the biggest natural ski jump hill in Canada and internationally recognized as one of the best in North America. The length and natural grade of its {{convert|600|m|ft|abbr=on}} hill made possible jumps of over {{convert|60| m|ft|abbr=on}}—the longest in Canada. It was also the only hill in Canada where world ski jumping records were set, in 1916, 1921, 1925, 1932, and 1933.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/bc/revelstoke/decouvrir-discover/hist/ski |title=The History of Skiing on Mount Revelstoke |access-date=2017-10-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018071701/https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/bc/revelstoke/decouvrir-discover/hist/ski |archive-date=2017-10-18 |dead-url=no |df= }} In 1935, the origins of the [[ski flying]] began in [[Planica]], Slovenia, where [[Josef Bradl]] became the first competitor in history to jump over {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}}. At the same venue, the first official jump over {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} was achieved in 1994, when [[Toni Nieminen]] landed at 203 metres.{{cite web|url=http://www.skisprungschanzen.com/EN/Ski+Jumps/SLO-Slovenia/Planica/0475-Letalnica/|title=Letalnica, Planica|publisher=skisprungschanzen.com|accessdate=13 March 2017}} In 1964 in [[Zakopane]], Poland, the large hill event was introduced at the [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]]. In the same year, the normal hill event was included on the Olympic programme at the [[1964 Winter Olympics]]. The team event was added later, at the [[1988 Winter Olympics]]. == Rules == === Hills === {{main|Ski jumping hill}} [[Image:Ski jumping hill profile.svg|thumb|upright=1.4|Model of a ski jumping hill. {{nowrap|A-B – point of departure}}; {{nowrap|t – take-off zone}}; {{nowrap|HS – total hill length}}; {{nowrap|P-L – landing area}}; {{nowrap|K – K-point}}]] A ski jumping hill is located on a steep slope, and it consists of the jumping ramp (''in-run''), take-off table, and a landing hill. Competitors glide down from a common point at the top of the in-run, achieving considerable speeds at the take-off table, where they take off with help of speed and their own leap. While airborne, they maintain an aerodynamic position with their bodies and skis, that would allow them to maximize the length of the jump. The landing slope is constructed so that the jumper's trajectory is near-parallel with it, and the athlete's relative height to the ground is gradually lost, allowing for a gentle and safe landing. The landing space is followed by an ''out-run'', a substantial flat or counter-inclined area that permits the skier to safely slow down.{{cite web|url=http://www.fis-ski.com/mm/Document/documentlibrary/Skijumping/03/20/22/StandardsfortheConstructionofJumpingHills2012_english_English.pdf |title=Standards for the Construction of Jumping Hills - 2012 | publisher=[[International Ski Federation]] |accessdate=14 March 2017}} The out-run area is fenced and surrounded by a public auditorium. The slopes are classified according to the distance that the competitors travel in the air, between the end of the table and the landing. Each hill has a [[construction point]] (''K-point''), which serves as a "target" that the competitors should reach. The classification of the hills are as follows:{{cite web |url=http://www.fis-ski.com/mm/Document/documentlibrary/Skijumping/03/19/96/ICR_JP_2012_Final_English.pdf |title=THE INTERNATIONAL SKI COMPETITION RULES (ICR)|publisher=[[International Ski Federation]] |accessdate=14 March 2017}} {|class=wikitable ! Class !! Construction point !! [[Hill size]] |- | Small hill || to 45 metres || to 50 metres |- | Medium hill || 45–74 m || 50–84 m |- | Normal hill || 75–99 m || 85–109 m |- | Large hill || 100–169 m || 110–184 m |- | [[Ski flying]] hill || over 170 m || over 185 m |} === Scoring system === Competitors are ranked according to a numerical score obtained by adding up components based on distance, style, inrun length (gate factor) and wind conditions. In the individual event, the scores from each skier's two competition jumps are combined to determine the winner. Distance score depends on the hill's K-point. For K-90 and K-120 competitions, the K-point is set at 90 metres and 120 metres, respectively. Competitors are awarded 60 points (normal and large hills) and 120 points (flying hills) if they land on the K-point. For every metre beyond the K-point, the competitor is awarded extra points; the typical value is 2 points per metre in small hills, 1.8 points in large hills and 1.2 points in ski flying hills. A competitor's distance is measured between the takeoff and the point where the feet came in full contact with the landing slope (for abnormal landings, touchpoint of one foot, or another body part is considered). Jumps are measured with accuracy of 0.5 metres for all competitions. {{cite web | url = http://www.fis-ski.com/mm/Document/documentlibrary/Skijumping/03/19/96/ICRSkiJumping2017_clean_English.pdf | title = The International Ski Competition Rules (ICR): Book III – Ski Jumping | date = October 2017 | access-date = March 19, 2018 | publisher = [[International Ski Federation]]}}{{rp|64–65}} [[Image:Telemark landing Miyanomori.jpg|thumb|Telemark landing]] During the competition, five judges are based in a tower to the side of the expected landing point. They can award up to 20 points each for jumping style, based on keeping the skis steady during flight, balance, optimal body position, and landing. The highest and lowest style scores are disregarded, with the remaining three scores added to the distance score.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/02/why-does-olympic-ski-jumping-need-judges/283875/|title=Why Does Olympic Ski Jumping Need Judges?|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=14 March 2017|publisher=theatlantic.com|author=Jim Pagels}} Gate and wind factors were introduced by the 2009 rules, to allow fairer comparison of results for a scoring compensation for variable outdoor conditions. Aerodynamics and take-off speed are important variables that affect the jump length, and if weather conditions change during a competition, the conditions will not be the same for all competitors. Gate factor is an adjustment made when the inrun (or start gate) length is adjusted from the initial position in order to provide optimal take-off speed. Since higher gates result in higher take-off speeds, and therefore present an advantage to competitors, points are subtracted when the starting gate is moved up, and added when the gate is lowered. An advanced calculation also determines compensation points for the actual unequal wind conditions at the time of the jump. These points are added or withdrawn from the original scores of the individual jump according to the wind conditions; when there is back wind, the points are added, and when there is front wind, the points are subtracted. Wind speed and direction are measured at five different points based on average value, which is determined before every competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.wsjusa.com/ski-jumping-101/ |title=Ski Jumping 101 |publisher=Women's Ski Jumping USA |access-date = March 19, 2018}} If two or more competitors finish the competition with the same number of points, they are given the same placing and receive same prizes. Ski jumpers below the minimum safe body mass index are penalized with a shorter maximum ski length, reducing the aerodynamic lift they can achieve. These rules have been credited with stopping the most severe cases of underweight athletes, but some competitors still lose weight to maximize the distance they can achieve.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/sports/olympics/12skijump.html|title=For Ski Jumpers, a Sliding Scale of Weight, Distance and Health|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=11 February 2010 | first = Jeré | last = Longman | date = February 11, 2010}} In order to prevent an unfair advantage due to a "sailing" effect of the ski jumping suit, material, thickness and relative size of the suit are regulated.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/ski-jumping-101-equipment|title=Ski jumping 101: Equipment| date = June 19, 2017 | work=NBC Olympics|access-date=2017-09-14|language=en}} == Techniques == {{for|details|Ski jumping techniques}} [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-61623-0009, Harald Pfeffer.jpg|thumb|Kongsberger technique]] Each jump is divided into four parts: in-run, take-off (jump), flight, and landing. By using the [[ski jumping techniques#V-style|V-style]], firstly pioneered by Swedish ski jumper [[Jan Boklöv]] in the mid-1980s, modern skiers are able to exceed the distance of the take-off hill by about 10% compared to the previous technique with parallel skis.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} Previous techniques included the [[Ski jumping techniques#Kongsberger|Kongsberger technique]], the [[Ski jumping techniques#D.C3.A4scher.2Fparallel|Däescher technique]] and the [[Ski jumping techniques#Windisch|Windisch technique]].{{cite web|url=http://www.skijumping-info.com/info-section/the-history/80-info/107-techniques.html|title=Development of ski jumping technique|publisher=skijumping-info.com|accessdate=15 January 2012|archive-date=29 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129035059/http://www.skijumping-info.com/info-section/the-history/80-info/107-techniques.html}} Until the mid-1960s, the ski jumper came down the in-run of the hill with both arms pointing forwards. This changed when the Däscher technique was pioneered by [[Andreas Däscher]] in the 1950s, as a modification of the Kongsberger and Windisch techniques. A lesser-used technique as of 2017 is the H-style which is essentially a combination of the parallel and V-styles, in which the skis are spread very wide apart and held parallel in an "H" shape. It is prominently used by [[Domen Prevc]]. Skiers are required to touch the ground in the Telemark landing style ({{lang-no|telemarksnedslag}}), named after the Norwegian county of [[Telemark]]. This involves the landing with one foot in front of the other with knees slightly bent, mimicking the style of [[Telemark skiing]]. Failure to execute a Telemark landing leads to the deduction of style points, issued by the judges.''Kunnskapsforlagets idrettsleksikon'' (Encyclopedia of Sports), Oslo: Kunnskapsforlaget, 1990. {{ISBN|82-573-0408-5}} == Major competitions == All major ski jumping competitions are organized by the [[International Ski Federation]]. The large hill ski jumping event was included at the [[Winter Olympic Games]] for the first time in [[1924 Winter Olympics|1924]], and has been contested at every Winter Olympics since then.{{cite news|url=http://www.infoplease.com/spot/winter-olympics-ski-jumping.html|title=Winter Olympics: Ski Jumping|publisher=infoplease.com|author1=John Gettings|author2=Christine Frantz|accessdate=14 March 2017}} The normal hill event was added in [[1964 Winter Olympics|1964]]. Since [[1992 Winter Olympics|1992]], the normal hill event is contested at the K-90 size hill; previously, it was contested at the K-60 hill. Women's debuted at the Winter Olympics in [[2014 Winter Olympics|2014]]. The [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup]] has been contested since the [[1979–80 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|1979–80]] season.{{cite web|url=http://www.fis-ski.com/ski-jumping/news-multimedia/news/article=facts-figures-about-the-world-cup-sapporo.html|title=Facts & Figures about the World Cup in Sapporo|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=14 March 2017|publisher=[[International Ski Federation]]}} It runs between November and March every season, and consists of 25–30 competitions at most prestigious hills across Europe, United States and Japan. Competitors are awarded a fixed number of points in each event according to their ranking, and the overall winner is the one with most accumulated points. [[FIS Ski Flying World Cup]] is contested as a sub-event of the World Cup, and competitors collect only the points scored at ski flying hills from the calendar. [[Image:FIS Sommer Grand Prix 2014 - 20140809 - Young jumping.jpg|thumb|A ski jumper after landing on a hill equipped for summer events]] The ski jumping at the [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] was first contested in 1925. The team event was introduced in 1982, while the women's event was first held in 2009. The [[FIS Ski Flying World Championships]] was first contested in 1972 in [[Planica]].{{cite web|url=http://www.slovenia.si/slovenia/society/sport/winning-disciplines/planica-cradle-of-slovenian-sport/|title=Planica – cradle of Slovenian sport|accessdate=14 March 2017|publisher=slovenia.si|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315003428/http://www.slovenia.si/slovenia/society/sport/winning-disciplines/planica-cradle-of-slovenian-sport/|archive-date=2017-03-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} The [[Four Hills Tournament]] has been contested since the 1952–53 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.vierschanzentournee.com/en/ergebnisse/tourneesieger |title=All Winners |website=Four Hills TournamentĐĐ It is contested around the New Year's Day at four venues – two in Germany ([[Oberstdorf]] and [[Garmisch-Partenkirchen]]) and two in Austria ([[Innsbruck]] and [[Bischofshofen]]), which are also scored for the World Cup. Those events are traditionally held in a slightly different format than other World Cup events (first round is held as a knockout event between 25 pairs of jumpers), and the overall winner is determined by adding up individual scores from every jump. Other competitions organised by the International Ski Federation include the [[FIS Ski Jumping Grand Prix]] (held in summer), [[FIS Ski Jumping Continental Cup|Continental Cup]], [[FIS Cup (ski jumping)|FIS Cup]], [[FIS Race (ski jumping)|FIS Race]], and [[FIS Ski Jumping Alpen Cup|Alpen Cup]]. == Women's participation == In January 1863 in [[Trysil]], Norway, at that time 16 years old Norwegian Ingrid Olsdatter Vestby, became the first-ever known female ski jumper, who participated in the competition. Her distance is not recorded.Haarstad, Kjell (1993): Skisportens oppkomst i Norge. Trondheim: Tapir. Women began competing at the high level since the [[2004–05 FIS Ski Jumping Continental Cup|2004–05 Continental Cup]] season.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/mattslater/2009/03/why_its_time_to_let_ladies_fly.html|title=Why it's time to let ladies fly|author=Matt Slater|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2 March 2009|accessdate=14 March 2017}} [[International Ski Federation]] organized three women's team events in this competition and so far the only team events in history of women's ski jumping. [[Image:20170205 Ski Jumping World Cup Ladies Hinzenbach 8927.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Sara Takanashi]] is the most successful female ski jumper, winning the [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]] title on four occasions.]] Women's made a premiere [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] performance in [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2009|2009]] in [[Liberec]]. The first world champion became American ski jumper [[Lindsey Van]].{{cite news|url=https://www.dnevnik.si/1042246241|title=Liberec: Svetovna prvakinja v skoki Lindsey Van, Manja Pograjc zasedla 24. mesto|publisher=dnevnik.si|date=20 February 2009|accessdate=14 March 2017|language=Slovenian|author=(sta)}} In the [[2011–12 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|2011–12]] season, women competed for the first time in the [[FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]]. The first event was held on 3 December 2011 at [[Lysgårdsbakken]] at normal hill in [[Lillehammer]], Norway. The first-ever female World Cup winner was [[Sarah Hendrickson]],{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/skijumping/story/_/id/7309917/us-teen-sarah-hendrickson-captures-inaugural-women-world-cup-ski-jump|title=Sarah Hendrickson, 17, wins ski jump|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=3 December 2011|accessdate=14 March 2017}} who also became the inaugural women's World Cup overall champion.{{cite news|url=http://www.ladies-skijumping.com/wiadomosci/352/Zao-Sarah-Hendrickson-wins-overall-World-Cup/|title=Zao: Sarah Hendrickson wins overall World Cup|author1=Stefan Diaz|author2=Egon Theiner|publisher=ladies-skijumping.com|date=3 March 2012|accessdate=14 March 2017}} Previously, women had only competed in [[FIS Ski Jumping Continental Cup|Continental Cup]] seasons. === 2014: Olympic Games === In 2006, the International Ski Federation proposed that women could compete at the [[2010 Winter Olympics]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/news/pressreleases/pressreleases2006/gacongressdecisions.html|title=FIS MEDIA INFO: Decisions of the 45th International Ski Congress in Vilamoura/Algarve|publisher=[[International Ski Federation]]|accessdate=14 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130123053734/http://www.fis-ski.com/uk/news/pressreleases/pressreleases2006/gacongressdecisions.html|archivedate=23 January 2013|df=}} but the proposal was rejected by the [[International Olympic Committee|IOC]] because of the low number of athletes and participating countries at the time.{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2006/11/28/sports/ME_SPT_OLY_IOC_Meetings.php|title=IOC approves skicross; rejects women's ski jumping|publisher=iht.com|accessdate=15 March 2009}} A group of fifteen competitive female ski jumpers later filed a suit against the [[Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games]] on the grounds that it violated the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] since men were competing.{{cite web|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n2/content/view/16139/|title=Female Ski Jumpers Seem Olympic Inclusion|publisher=Epoch Times|accessdate=14 November 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/1109/p17s03-ussc.html|title=Why women can't ski jump in the Winter Olympics|publisher=Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=14 November 2014}} The suit failed, with the judge ruling that the situation was not governed by the charter. A further milestone was reached when women's ski jumping was included as part of the [[2014 Winter Olympics]] at normal hill event. The first Olympic champion was [[Carina Vogt]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/winter-olympics/26057176|title=Sochi 2014: Carina Vogt wins women’s ski jumping gold|author=Rob Hodgetts|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=11 February 2014|accessdate=14 March 2017}} == Record jumps == {{for|the world records|List of longest ski jumps}} {{see also|List of national ski-jumping records}} [[File:VikersundbakkenWorld Cup Ski flying 2011.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The all-time longest jump was achieved in Vikersund in 2017.]] Since 1936, when the first jump beyond {{convert|100|m|ft}} was made, all world records in the sport have been made in the discipline of [[ski flying]]. As of March 2017, the official world record for the longest ski jump is {{convert|253.5|m|ft|abbr=on}}, set by [[Stefan Kraft]] at [[Vikersundbakken]] in [[Vikersund]], Norway. Two years prior, also in Vikersund, [[Dimitry Vassiliev]] reached {{convert|254|m|ft|abbr=on}} but fell upon landing; his jump is unofficially the longest ever made.{{cite web|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/world-of-sport/ski-jump-world-record-broken-for-second-time-in-two-days-as-anders-fannemel-flies-to-glory-164459525.html|author=[[Eurosport]]|title=Ski jump world record broken for second time in two days as Anders Fannemel flies to glory|date=15 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217025612/https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/world-of-sport/ski-jump-world-record-broken-for-second-time-in-two-days-as-anders-fannemel-flies-to-glory-164459525.html|archivedate=17 February 2015|df=}} [[Daniela Iraschko-Stolz]] has held the women's world record of {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} since 2003. [[Image:Josef Bradl.JPG|thumb|right|upright|[[Sepp Bradl]] became the first ski jumper to surpass 100 metres in 1936.]] [[Image:Austria 2014 Iraschko-Stolz.jpg|thumb|right|upright|In 2003, [[Daniela Iraschko]] became the only female ski jumper in history to reach 200 metres.]] The lists below show the progression of world records through history at 50-meter milestones. Only official results are listed, invalid jumps are not included. === Men === {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="background:#fff; font-size:86%; line-height:16px; [[Kazuyoshi Funaki]] is the only one in history who achieved this more than once. {{unreferenced|date=July 2014}} {{Use Hong Kong English|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Somebody Up There Likes Me | image = SomebodyUpThereLikesMe.jpg | alt = | caption = DVD cover | film name = {{Film name | traditional = 浪漫風暴 | simplified = 浪漫风暴 | pinyin = Làng Màn Fēng Bào | jyutping = Long6 Maan6 Fung1 Bou6 }} | director = Patrick Leung | producer = [[John Woo]] | writer = | screenplay = Chan Hing-ka | story = | based on = | starring = [[Aaron Kwok]]
[[Carmen Lee]]
[[Sammo Hung]] | narrator = | music = Dennie Wong | cinematography = [[Arthur Wong]]
Cheung Man-po | editing = [[David Wu (Hong Kong actor)|David Wu]] | studio = Long Shong Pictures
Milestone Films | distributor = Newport Entertainment | released = {{start date|df=y|1996|1|12}} | runtime = 114 minutes | country = Hong Kong | language = [[Cantonese]] | budget = | gross = HK$11,611,563 }} '''''Somebody Up There Likes Me''''' is a 1996 [[Hong Kong action cinema|Hong Kong action]] [[romance film]] directed by Patrick Leung and starring [[Aaron Kwok]], [[Carmen Lee]] and [[Sammo Hung]]. ==Plot== With encouragement from his girlfriend, Gloria ([[Carmen Lee]]), Ken Wong ([[Aaron Kwok]]), a rebellious and stubborn youth, decides to focus on the sport of boxing. During a match, Ken accidentally kills Gloria's older brother, Rocky ([[Michael Tong]]), and the two break up. Ken is unwilling to give up his boxing career and seeks tuition from boxing master, Black Jack Hung ([[Sammo Hung]]). He also manages to reconcile with Gloria, who supports Ken returning to the ring to complete her brother's wish to challenge Yamada Motokazu (Sawada Kenya), the boxing champion of Asia. Due to constantly suffering blows to his head, Ken's is physically traumatized and once able to defeat Yamada, he also collapses. ==Cast== {{div col}} *[[Aaron Kwok]] as Ken Wong *[[Carmen Lee]] as Gloria Chan *[[Sammo Hung]] as Black Jack Hung *[[Michael Tong]] as Rocky Chan *Hilary Tsui as Pam *May Law as Ken's mother *[[Kenya Sawada|Sawada Kenya]] as Yamamda Moyokazu *[[Jun Kunimura]] as Yamada's manager *[[Vincent Kok]] as Loud Boxing Spectator *[[Clifton Ko]] as Pau *[[Ann Hui]] as Teacher *[[Lawrence Ah Mon]] as Doctor *Bonnie Wong as Gloria and Rocky's mother *Perry Chiu as Ken's sister *Chan Tak-hing as Big B / Den *Ken Lok as Pang *[[Fruit Chan]] as Policeman *[[Alan Mak (director)|Alan Mak]] as Policeman *Benny Lam as Po *Lee Man-piu as Ken's Former Master *Winston Yeh as Keith Wong (Ken's father) *Chang Yuk-chuen as Chuen {{div col end}} ==Box office== The film grossed HK$11,611,563 at the Hong Kong box office during its theatrical run from 12 January to 14 February 1996 in [[Hong Kong]]. ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%;" ; |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="4" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Accolades |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! style="background:#ccc| Ceremony ! style="background:#ccc| Category ! style="background:#ccc| Recipient ! style="background:#ccc| Outcome |- |rowspan=2|'''[[16th Hong Kong Film Awards]]''' |[[Hong Kong Film Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]] |[[Arthur Wong]] |{{Nom}} |- |Best Film Editing |[[David Wu (Hong Kong actor)|David Wu]] |{{Nom}} |- |} ==External links== *{{hkmdb title|8123|Somebody Up There Likes Me}} *''[http://www.hkcinemagic.com/en/movie.asp?id=1048 Somebody Up There Likes Me]'' at [[Hong Kong Cinemagic]] *{{imdb title|0116820}} *[http://www.lovehkfilm.com/reviews/somebody_up_there_likes_me.htm ''Somebody Up There Likes Me'' film review] at LoveHKFilm.com [[Category:Hong Kong films]] [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:1990s action films]] [[Category:1990s romantic drama films]] [[Category:1990s martial arts films]] [[Category:Hong Kong action films]] [[Category:Hong Kong martial arts films]] [[category:Hong Kong romance films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:Underground fighting films]] [[Category:Martial arts tournament films]] [[Category:Cantonese-language films]] [[Category:Sports in fiction]] [[Category:Films set in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Films shot in Hong Kong]] [[Category:Heroic bloodshed films]]

{{original research|date=August 2014}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Sports Illustrated'' cover jinx}} [[File:Sports Illustrated cover January 21 2002.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The magazine cover for the January 21, 2002 issue of ''Sports Illustrated''.]]
The '''''Sports Illustrated'' so-called cover jinx''' is an [[urban legend]] that states that individuals or teams who appear on the cover of the ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' magazine will subsequently be [[jinx]]ed (experience bad luck).
==Explanations== A common explanation for the perceived effect is that athletes are generally featured on the cover after an exceptionally good performance, which might be an [[outlier]] compared to their usual level of performance. Therefore, their future performance is likely to display [[regression toward the mean]] and be less impressive by comparison.<ref>Goldacre, Ben. ''Bad Science''. Page 39. London: Fourth Estate, 2008.</ref> This decline in performance would then be misperceived as being related to, or even possibly caused by, the appearance on the magazine cover.
Most athletes that seemed to suffer the jinx most typically suffered because of an injury to their body, or some other bad luck following their appearance. One prime candidate for this explanation is [[Eddie Mathews]] who suffered a broken hand while the team's nine game winning streak came to a close following the cover. In this case, the odds are that a player will suffer an injury while playing any given sport with injuries a given in a physical contact sport such American football or baseball which is what Mathews played. Even injuries in individual sports such as skiing can fall under this explanation as it is common to make a bad move in this sport and get caught up in a massive mistake of the athlete's own doing which results in injury. Finally, winning and losing streaks come to a close in all sports and this includes Milwaukee's nine-game winning streak in 1954. This makes the [[1972 Miami Dolphins season|1972 Miami Dolphins]] perfect season, [[2007 New England Patriots season|2007 New England Patriots]] perfect regular season, and the [[2008 Detroit Lions season|2008 Detroit Lions]] winless season all the more remarkable.
''SI'' addressed its own opinions on the alleged cover jinx in a 2002 issue that featured a [[black cat]] on its cover.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/vault/2002/01/21/8107599/that-old-black-magic-millions-of-superstitious-readersand-many-athletesbelieve-that-an-appearance-on-sports-illustrateds-cover-is-the-kiss-of-death-but-is-there-really-such-a-thing-as-the-si-jinx |title=The Cover That No One Would Pose for: Is the SI Jinx for Real? |publisher=[[CNN]] and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' |date=2002-01-21 |accessdate=2017-08-10 }}</ref>
==Notable contradictions to so-called curse== While the list of "examples" of the so-called jinx may be extensive, records contradict the existence of a curse.<ref> {{cite web|title=Sports Illustrated|url=http://i.cnn.net/si/si_online/covers/images/1984/1210_large.jpg|publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref> *[[Michael Jordan]] holds the cover record of 50 appearances, none of which hindered his success.
*[[Muhammad Ali]] appeared on [[Sports Illustrated#Cover history|40 covers]], experienced a typical array of luck in his professional and personal life, and was named the ''Sports Illustrated'' [[Sports Illustrated#Sportsman of the Century|Sportsman of the Century]], owing to skill, not luck.
*[[Vince Young]] also discredited the ''Sports Illustrated'' jinx by appearing on the cover of ''Sports Illustrated'' twice during Texas' National Championship season.<ref> {{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0201/25/ltm.01.html|title=Is Their (sic) a "Sports Illustrated" Cover Jinx?|publisher=[[CNN]]|author=[[Paula Zahn]]|date=2002-01-25|accessdate=2007-08-28}}</ref>
*[[Emmitt Smith]] appeared on the cover the same week the [[Dallas Cowboys]] won [[Super Bowl XXVIII]]. In the ''[[America's Game]]'' documentary, Smith recalled that he adamantly wanted off the cover for fear of the jinx. Regardless, the Cowboys went on to win their second consecutive title of the 1990s, and fourth in team history.
*[[Tony Dorsett]] appeared on the cover under the title of "Heading for the Heisman" in 1976 and indeed won the [[Heisman Trophy]] that year.
* [[Andrew McCutchen]] was featured on a September 2013 cover, during a season in which he later won the [[National League MVP Award]] and led the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] to their first playoff berth in twenty years.
* The [[2013 Seattle Seahawks season|2013 Seattle Seahawks]] appeared on a September 2013 cover in which the magazine predicted a [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] win for the team; the Seahawks won the Super Bowl the following February.
* [[George Springer]] was featured on the cover of the June 30, 2014 issue, which also predicted that the [[Houston Astros]] would win the [[2017 World Series]]; not only did the Astros win the World Series in 2017, but Springer was named MVP of that series.
*[[Stephen Curry]] was featured on two consecutive May 2015 covers and led the [[Golden State Warriors]] to their first NBA title in forty years.
* [[Kyrie Irving]] was featured on the June 6, 2016 cover and led the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] to their first NBA title in franchise history.
* [[Usain Bolt]] was featured on the July 18, 2016 cover promoting his quest as the fastest human ever and won gold in the 100, 200, and 4x100 meter relay at the 2016 Rio Olympics.
* The [[Chicago Cubs]] appeared on the October 10, 2016 cover in which the magazine predicted a [[2016 World Series]] win for the team; indeed, the Cubs won the World Series. [[Lamar Jackson]] appeared on the September 26, 2016 issue and later won the [[Heisman Trophy]] that year.
==Notable incidences== ===1954–1960=== *August 16, 1954: [[Atlanta Braves|Milwaukee Braves]] third baseman [[Eddie Mathews]] became the first person to appear on the cover of ''Sports Illustrated.'' The Braves would have a nine-game winning streak snapped, and a broken hand later caused Mathews to miss seven games. *January 31, 1955: Skier [[Jill Kinmont]] suffered a near-fatal crash at [[Alta Ski Area|Alta, Utah]] the same week that she appeared on the cover, and was left paralyzed from the chest down. *March 14, 1955: [[University of Colorado]] skier [[Buddy Werner|Wallace "Buddy" Werner]] finished eleventh in the men's downhill at the [[Alpine skiing at the 1956 Winter Olympics|1956 Winter Olympics]]. In December 1959, just two months before the [[Alpine skiing at the 1960 Winter Olympics|1960 Winter Olympics]], Werner sustained a broken leg. ''(see January 28, 1964)''. *May 28, 1956: [[1956 Indianapolis 500|Indy 500]] winner [[Bob Sweikert]] was featured on the cover. Less than three weeks later he died in a sprint car crash. *February 18, 1957: Basketball player [[Jim Krebs]] was killed by a falling tree during a storm in 1965 at age 29. *May 27, 1957: Race driver [[Jimmy Bryan]], who would win the [[Indianapolis 500]] in 1958, was killed in a race crash in [[Langhorne Speedway]] in 1960 at age 34. *November 18, 1957: [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma Sooner]] [[Clendon Thomas]] appeared on the cover, along with others on the Sooner sideline, with the headline "Why Oklahoma is Unbeatable." The next game of that season Oklahoma lost to [[1957 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]], ending their NCAA Division I record 47-game winning streak. *May 26, 1958: Race car driver [[Pat O'Connor (racing driver)|Pat O'Connor]] appeared on the cover. He died four days later on the first lap of the [[1958 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]]. *March 23, 1959: [[Prince Aly Khan]], featured in a cover story on his race horses, died just over a year later of injuries sustained in a car crash at age 48. *February 15, 1960: After gracing the cover of the Winter Olympics preview issue, Soviet speed skater Gennady Voronin was hampered by injury and finished out of the medals at Squaw Valley. Troubles mounted after he also missed the 1964 games due to injury, as Voronin began to abuse alcohol. Unable to deal with the success of his wife, fellow speed skater and four-time world champion [[Inga Artamonova]], Voronin was convicted of stabbing her to death in 1966 and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.<ref>[https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/vo/gennady-voronin-1.html Sports-Reference.com], Gennady Voronin page (retrieved 10 May 2015)</ref> *March 28, 1960: For a story on [[wet fly]] [[fly fishing|fishing]],<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/1960/03/28/583828/the-art-of-fishing-with-the-wet-fly The Art of Fishing With The Wet Fly], Sports Illustrated, 28 March 1960 (retrieved 11 May 2015)</ref> the cover featured an array of ten images<ref>[http://www.krakov.net/si/images/1960/0328_large.jpg Cover scan] of 28 March 1960 issue of Sports Illustrated (retrieved 11 May 2015).</ref> They included a photo of the fly-tying pioneer James E. Leisenring (1878–1951)<ref>Whitelaw, Ian. [https://books.google.com/books?id=aMeaBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT223&lpg=PT223&dq=Vernon+%22Pete%22+Hidy&source=bl&ots=ldSC4yflPS&sig=7Wl9PsrHa2YK-B_AwVHmLmog0FQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WCRQVfbOJcLFsAX3mYDwCQ&ved=0CFYQ6AEwDg#v=onepage&q=James%20Leisenring%20%281878-1951%29&f=false The History of Fly-Fishing in Fifty Flies], Stewart, Tabori and Chang (7 April 2015), retrieved 11 May 2015.</ref> and sketches by artist Anthony Ravielli depicting world flycasting champion Johnny Dieckman (at upper right on the cover) and Vernon S. "Pete" Hidy (on the bottom row of the cover)<ref>[http://www.codex99.com/illustration/9.html codex99.com], "Ravielli on Sport" (accessed 11 May 2015).</ref> Less than two years later, the 35-year-old Dieckman was one of 87 passengers who perished in the crash of [[American Airlines Flight 1]].<ref>"Fly Casting Champ Dies", [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=728&dat=19620308&id=Q8svAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tkEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2961,1492698&hl=en The St. Maurice Valley Chronicle] (Three Rivers, Quebec, Canada), page 6, published 8 March 1962 (retrieved 11 May 2015).</ref> *October 31, 1960: [[1960 Formula One season|Formula One world champion]] [[Jack Brabham]] appears on the cover. For the [[1961 Formula One season|following season]], Brabham found himself outclassed by a newer generation of cars,<ref>Lawrence (1998) p. 87{{cite book | last = Lawrence | first = Mike | title = Grand Prix Cars 1945–1965 | publisher=Motor Racing Publications | year = 1998 | isbn = 1-899870-39-3}}</ref> as well retiring from a number of races.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/drivdet/brabhja01/1961/F|title=Jack Brabham 1961 Formula One Results - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *December 26, 1960: President-elect [[John F. Kennedy]] and his wife [[Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy]] are shown sailing off [[Cape Cod]]. The president would be [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassinated]] less than three years later.
===1961–1970=== *February 13, 1961: 16-year-old [[Laurence Owen]], the 1961 U.S. National and North American Figure Skating Champion appeared on the cover as "America's Most Exciting Girl Skater". On February 15, she and the rest of the U.S. figure skating team were [[Sabena Flight 548|killed in a plane crash]] near [[Brussels]], Belgium while en route to the World Figure Skating Championships in [[Prague]], [[Czechoslovakia]].<!--The modern Czech Republic didn't exist until 1993.--> *May 29, 1961: [[Johnny Boyd]] appears uncredited driving in preparation for the [[1961 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]], he retired during the race with clutch problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/rquery?id=41&trk=t0&series=UO&cn=1&yr=1961|title=Car number 41 in 1961 AAA / USAC Champ Car Series - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *March 26, 1962: Less than 8 months after appearing on the cover, Mexican race driver [[Ricardo Rodriguez (racing driver)|Ricardo Rodriguez]] was killed at age 20 in a crash during the first day of practice for the [[1962 Mexican Grand Prix]]. *March 18, 1963: On the Final Four preview cover,<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1963/03/18 Cover image from 18 March 1963], si.com (retrieved 15 May 2015).</ref> [[Cincinnati Bearcats men's basketball|Cincinnati Bearcats]] guard Larry Shingleton was shown cutting down the nets following his team's second straight NCAA championship in 1962. In the [[1963 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|1963 championship game]] on March 23, Shingleton missed a free throw with 12 seconds left that would have given Cincinnati a three-point lead and all but clinched another title. Instead, [[1962–63 Loyola Ramblers men's basketball team|Loyola (Chicago)]] tied the game in regulation and won it in overtime.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1987-11-01/sports/8703230680_1_loyola-ramblers-george-ireland-college-basketball Chicago Tribune], "March 23, 1963 Vic Rouse`s Tip-in As Time Expires In Overtime Gives Loyola A 60–58 Victory Over Defending Champion Cincinnati", 1 November 1987 (retrieved 15 May 2015).</ref> *June 17, 1963: This [[1963 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] preview issue featured defending champion [[Jack Nicklaus]] on the cover. He would shoot rounds of 76 and 77, missing the cut by a stroke. * July 8, 1963: World champion fisherman Jon Tarantino, featured in a cover story on fly casting,<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/1963/07/08/595046/the-worlds-master-caster The World's Master Caster], Sports Illustrated via SI.com, 8 July 1963 (retrieved 17 May 2015).</ref> was shot to death 10 years later, on 11 June 1973, in a robbery at his family's San Francisco fish and poultry market.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/52056423/ San Mateo (CA) Times via newspapers.com] (subscription required), 12 June 1973 (retrieved 17 May 2015). (''SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) – Jon E. Tarantino, the "undisputed master of fly-casting", was found shot to death Monday in his family's fish and poultry market. Tarantino was shot once in the forehead in a robbery, police said. Tarantino held 12 world championships in fly casting."'')</ref> *November 25, 1963: [[Chicago Bears]] running back [[Willie Galimore]] was killed in a car crash at age 29 along with 28-year-old teammate [[Bo Farrington]] on July 27, 1964. *January 28, 1964: The Winter Olympics preview issue marked the second cover appearance for skier [[Buddy Werner|Wallace "Buddy" Werner]] ''(see March 14, 1955).'' He finished out of the medals at the [[Alpine skiing at the 1964 Winter Olympics|1964 games]], and a far worse fate befell him two months later when he was killed in an avalanche near [[St. Moritz]] in the [[Swiss Alps]] at age 28. *November 23, 1964: A year to the day after the [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassination]] of President [[John F. Kennedy]], the cover featured a rendering<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1964/11/23 Sports Illustrated online cover archive] (retrieved 18 May 2015).</ref> of his personal ski instructor,<ref>[http://www.arlski.at/index_e.html Web site for Bernard Falch ski school], translated to English (retrieved 18 May 2015).</ref> Helmut Falch of Austria. An accident would later leave Falch paralyzed,<ref>[http://www.arlski.at/buchtipp_e.html Overview of Helmut Falch autobiography], translated to English (retrieved 18 May 2015).</ref> though he went on to win four [[List of Paralympic medalists in alpine skiing|Paralympic gold medals in alpine skiing]]. *March 15, 1965: Golfer [[Tony Lema]], previously featured on the 23 March 1964 cover,<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1964/03/23 Sports Illustrated cover archive] (retrieved 18 May 2015)/</ref> appeared this week in an artist's rendition.<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1965/03/15 Sports Illustrated cover archive] (retrieved 18 May 2015)/</ref> In July 1966, the 32-year-old Lema and his wife Betty, 30, were killed along with the two co-pilots when the private plane they chartered to travel between tournaments crashed in Lansing, Illinois. *March 22, 1965: Boxer [[Willie Pastrano]], the world light heavyweight champion at age 29, appears with the caption, "Ready to defend his title."<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1965/03/22 Sports Illustrated cover archive] (retrieved 18 May 2015)/</ref> On March 30, he lost the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] and [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] crowns to [[José Torres]] on a 9th-round technical knock-out. It would be the final bout of Pastrano's career. *March 29, 1965: [[1964–65 UCLA Bruins men's basketball team|UCLA]]'s [[Gail Goodrich]] was shown shooting against [[1964–65 Michigan Wolverines men's basketball team|Michigan]] center [[Bill Buntin]] during the Bruins' [[1965 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA basketball championship]] win.<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1965/03/29 Sports Illustrated cover archive] (retrieved 18 May 2015). ''NOTE: The caption provided by Sports Illustrated states that the Michigan defender is Cazzie Russell. This is an error, as Russell wore jersey number 33 for Michigan. Buntin wore number 22, as shown in the photo on his Wikipedia page. Further evidence provided by this [http://www.aadl.org/taxonomy/term/46645?page=1 team picture] signed by all Michigan players.''</ref> Buntin died suddenly three years later of a heart attack while playing a pick-up basketball game at age 26. *May 30, 1966: For the [[Indianapolis 500]] preview issue, race driver [[Johnny Boyd]] made his second appearance<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1966/05/30 Sports Illustrated cover archive] (retrieved 22 May 2015)/</ref> on the cover (see 29 May 1961). Boyd managed to avoid a 14-car wreck on the first lap of the [[1966 Indianapolis 500|1966 race]] but, shortly after the green flag restart, he crashed on turn 1 having completed just five laps in what would be his final Indy 500. *May 1, 1967: [[Chaparral Cars|Chaparral]]'s [[Jim Hall (racing driver)|Jim Hall]], who appeared along with his Chaparral 2F on the cover, would go on to suffer from a number of mishaps for the rest of the decade. At the [[1967 World Sportscar Championship season|end of the season]], that car found itself ineligible for competition through controversial rule changes.<ref>http://www.motorsportmagazine.com/race/racing-history/phil-hill-and-the-chaparral-2f/</ref> For the [[1969 Can-Am season|following year]], Hall collided with another car at the [[Stardust Grand Prix]], ending his racing career effectively. In [[1969 Can-Am season|1969]], his Chaparral 2H suffered from a poor season and in [[1970 Can-Am season|1970]], the innovative 2J fan-car, despite its performance, proved to be unreliable and following protests from competitors, was banned from competition at the end of the season. Hall and his team had to wait until the end of the decade for any success. *June 19, 1967: The boxing success of welterweight "Gypsy" Joe Harris, who lost sight in his right eye at age 11, earned him cover recognition<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1967/06/19 SI.com vault], 19 June 1967 cover (accessed 15 June 2015).</ref> despite the handicap which, at the time, had not yet been publicized nor discovered by boxing regulators. However, on 11 October 1968 (about two months after his first career loss in 25 career bouts) a routine doctor's examination of inflammation in the eye revealed his visual impairment. Stripped of his boxing license and unable to hold gainful employment thereafter, Harris fell into a life of drug and alcohol abuse before dying in 1990 at age 44.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-02-26/sports/8903230019_1_pennsylvania-state-athletic-commission-street-fight-gypsy-joe-harris "Gypsy Joe Came Close To A Title, But Then..."], Chicago Tribune, 26 February 1989 (accessed 15 June 2015).</ref><ref>[http://articles.philly.com/1990-03-07/sports/25903674_1_street-fight-emile-griffith-eye "Gypsy Joe Harris, Boxer, Dead At 44"], Philly.com, 7 March 1990 (accessed 15 June 2015).</ref> *July 31, 1967: An unnamed left-handed pitcher (or model) dons the cover<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1967/07/31 SI.com vault], cover image for 31 July 1967 issue (accessed 16 June 2015).</ref> for a story on the then-prevalent use of the illegal spitball pitch. The article prominently mentions [[Jack Hamilton (baseball)|Jack Hamilton]] of the [[California Angels]], with [[Washington Senators (1961–71)|Washington Senators]] manager [[Gil Hodges]] opining that Hamilton throws "the most flagrant spitter I ever saw ... It was the worst exhibition I've seen in baseball ... He made a farce of the game. Everyone knows that 90% of the pitchers in our league have thrown a spitter at one time or another, but none continues to break the rule like Hamilton."<ref>Weiskopf, Herman. [https://www.si.com/vault/1967/07/31/609382/the-infamous-spitter The Infamous Spitter], ''Sports Illustrated'', 31 July 1967 (accessed 16 June 2015).</ref> On 18 August 1967, an errant Hamilton pitch shattered the face and left eye socket of [[Boston Red Sox]] outfielder [[Tony Conigliaro]], who was in the midst of a stellar season. Conigliaro (who would appear with his grotesquely blackened eye on the 22 June 1970 cover<ref>[https://www.si.com/vault/cover/1970/06/22 SI.com vault], cover image for 22 June 1970 issue (accessed 16 June 2015).</ref>), was knocked out of action for the [[1967 World Series]], missed all of 1968, and continued to struggle with vision problems before retiring at age 30. The incident also scarred Hamilton, who would never again pitch inside so aggressively against hitters and lost effectiveness before leaving the sport less than two years later. Hamilton has steadfastly denied that the pitch to Conigliaro was a spitball despite contradictory statements from his own teammates.<ref>[http://www.cantstopthebleeding.com/45-years-ago-the-pitched-that-changed-tony-cs-life 45 Years Ago : The Pitch That Changed Tony C’s Life], cantstopthebleeding.com, 18 August 2012 (accessed 16 June 2015).</ref> *May 13, 1968: [[Graham Hill]] appeared driving the turbine powered and four-wheel drive [[Lotus 56]] in preparation for the [[1968 Indianapolis 500|Indianapolis 500]]. He crashed out during the race, his teammates retired the race with fuel shaft failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1968_Indianapolis_500/UO|title=1968 Indianapolis 500 - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> Turbine power and four-wheel drive was banned at the end of the season. *June 9, 1969: [[Lee Trevino]] appeared on the cover as part of a preview to the [[1969 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]. The defending champion failed to make the cut.
===1970–1980=== *August 31, 1970: Dallas Cowboy Les Shy appeared on the cover... 14 days later he was waived by the Cowboys but was picked up by the New York Giants. *June 7, 1971: [[Al Unser]] and [[Peter Revson]] appeared on the cover celebrating their 1st and 2nd finish in the [[1971 Indianapolis 500]]. Shortly after this publication, Unser began his string of retirements for the rest of that season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/rquery?id=1&trk=t0&series=UO&cn=1&yr=1971|title=Car number 1 in 1971 AAA / USAC Champ Car Series - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *September 11, 1972: Two-time defending national champion [[1972 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] was featured on the cover of the college football preview edition with the headline "Nebraska Goes For Three Straight". The Huskers were upset in the very first game of the 1972 season by UCLA, and finish 9–2–1. Similar occurrences took place in 1978, 1984, and 1996. *January 7, 1974: Eventual [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]r [[Fran Tarkenton]] appeared on the cover as The [[Minnesota Vikings]] defeat The [[Dallas Cowboys]] at [[Texas Stadium]] in the [[NFC Championship Game]] to advance to [[Super Bowl VIII]], where they would lose to [[Super Bowl MVP]] [[Larry Csonka]] and The [[Miami Dolphins]]. *June 27, 1976: [[Ken Norton]] appeared on the cover just prior to his third fight with [[Muhammad Ali]], and lost a highly disputed decision. *December 5, 1977: [[Earl Campbell]] and the 11–0 [[1977 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas Longhorns]] appeared on the cover. They lost their next game, the [[Cotton Bowl Classic|Cotton Bowl]], to [[1977 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]]. *March 20, 1978: [[Kansas City Royals]] shortstop [[Clint Hurdle]] appeared on the cover with the words "This Year's Phenom." Hurdle would go on to hit just .264 with seven home runs and 56 runs batted in while appearing in 133 games in 1978. Hurdle would not appear in a single [[MLB All-Star Game]] in his ten years as a player in [[Major League Baseball]] and compiled a lifetime batting average of just .259 with 32 home runs in 193 runs batted in for the Royals, [[Cincinnati Reds]], [[New York Mets]], and [[St. Louis Cardinals]] (he did, however, make an appearance in the World Series in 1980 with the Royals). *June 5, 1978: [[Al Unser]] appeared on the cover celebrating his third win; in his next two races, he crashed out<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1978_Molson_Diamond_Indy/UO|title=1978 Molson Diamond Indy - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> and ran out of fuel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1978_Rex_Mays_Classic/UO|title=1978 Rex Mays Classic - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> However this jinx was short lived as he scored a win for the next round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1978_Schaefer_500/UO|title=1978 Schaefer 500 - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *June 6, 1978: [[Ken Norton]] again appeared on the cover, this time before his first title defense against [[Larry Holmes]], who beat him in a split decision by one single point. *June 26, 1978: [[Andy North]] appears on the cover after winning the [[1978 U.S. Open (golf)|1978 U.S. Open]]. He would not win another PGA Tour event for seven years, which was the [[1985 U.S. Open (golf)|1985 U.S. Open]]. In a "repeat" of the "curse", after his appearance on the June 24, 1985 cover (for winning the 1985 U.S. Open), North would never win another PGA Tour event. *August 7, 1978: [[Pete Rose]] appeared on the cover the same week that his 44-game hitting streak ended. *November 20, 1978: Nebraska running back [[Rick Berns]] was featured after the [[1978 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Cornhuskers]] defeated #1 ranked [[1978 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] and appeared to be headed towards a showdown with Penn State for the national championship. But they lost at home to unranked [[1978 Missouri Tigers football team|Missouri]] the very next week, and were knocked out of the title picture. They were then forced to play a controversial rematch with Oklahoma in the [[1979 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]], which the revenge-minded Sooners won 31–24.
===1981–1990=== *May 25, 1981: [[A. J. Foyt]] appeared on the cover with the headline "Foyt Goes for a Fifth 500". Despite starting third, he ended up [[1981 Indianapolis 500|finishing 13th]].<ref name="racing-reference.info">{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1981_Indianapolis_500/UO|title=1981 Indianapolis 500 - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *September 14, 1981: [[Thomas Hearns]] was featured on the cover the week before his fight with [[Sugar Ray Leonard]], who knocks him out in the 14th round. *June 7, 1982: Boxer [[Gerry Cooney]] appeared on the cover before his fight with [[Larry Holmes]], who dispatched him in 13 rounds four days later. *July 30, 1984: [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] linebacker [[Jack Lambert (American football)|Jack Lambert]] appeared on the cover with an interview with the headline "The Man of Steel." Lambert would miss most of the [[1984 Pittsburgh Steelers season|1984 season]] with a [[turf toe]] injury and subsequently retired. *October 1, 1984: [[1984 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] running back Jeff Smith appeared on the cover with the headline "The Big Red Machine" after the #1 ranked Huskers routed 8th-ranked UCLA 42–3 at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena. They lost the following week to an unranked [[Syracuse Orange football|Syracuse]] squad that finished the season 6–5. Smith's senior season was eventually slowed by a re-injured ankle. *June 3, 1985: [[Danny Sullivan]] earned his cover appearance following his [[1985 Indianapolis 500|remarkable "Spin and Win" victory at the Indy 500]]. A day prior to this appearance, he had already begun a string of retirements for another two months.<ref>http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1985_Stroh%27s_G.I._Joe%27s_200/R</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1985_Meadowlands_United_States_Grand_Prix/R|title=1985 Meadowlands United States Grand Prix - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/1985_Michigan_500/R|title=1985 Michigan 500 - Racing-Reference.info|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *July 21, 1986: [[Jim Kelly]] was shown in a [[New Jersey Generals]] uniform in a preview of the [[1986 USFL season|1986]] [[United States Football League]] season. The USFL lost its pivotal antitrust lawsuit eight days later, and Kelly would never play for the Generals, joining the NFL's [[Buffalo Bills]] in time for the 1986 preseason.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/9019/index.htm |title=Jim Kelly, Football, New Jersey Generals – 07.21.86 – SI Vault |date=9 August 2009 |publisher= |accessdate=5 July 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809145034/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/9019/index.htm |archivedate=August 9, 2009 }}</ref> *January 12, 1987: The [[Cleveland Browns]]' [[Ozzie Newsome]] appeared on the cover that featured the headline "NEVER SAY DIE" after an amazing Browns AFC Playoff win over the [[New York Jets]]. One week later, The Browns would lose to the [[Denver Broncos]] in yet another epic AFC Playoff game featuring [[John Elway]] and [[The Drive]]. *January 19, 1987: The Denver Broncos' placekicker [[Rich Karlis]] who appeared on the cover celebrated his game-winning field goal over the Cleveland Browns in overtime to help the Broncos advance to [[Super Bowl XXI]] where in their next game they would fall to the [[New York Giants]]. *April 6, 1987: The [[Cleveland Indians]], with [[Joe Carter]] and [[Cory Snyder]], were featured in the cover with the headline "INDIAN UPRISING", and being predicted as the best team in the American League. While both men would have a good season, the Indians would lose 101 games, the most of any team [[1987 Major League Baseball season|that season]]. *October 5, 1987: [[Lloyd Moseby]] appeared on the cover with the caption "Here Comes Toronto". The [[Toronto Blue Jays|Blue Jays]] would lose their last seven games of the season, blowing a 3.5 game lead in the [[American League East]]. Ironically, they were eliminated in the final game of the season October 4, one day before the cover date. This is also a proof of the disadvantage of print media which has a fixed deadline though the shipment date is sometimes in advance of the cover date. *June 20, 1988: [[Michael Spinks]] appeared on the cover before his fight with [[Mike Tyson]] with the quote, "Don't count me out". Tyson promptly knocked him out, and into retirement, in just 91 seconds a week later. *September 26, 1988: [[Boston Red Sox]] outfielder [[Dwight Evans]] appeared on the cover and went 4-for-30 in a two-week span including the Boston Red Sox being swept out of the [[1988 American League Championship Series|ALCS]] by the Oakland Athletics. *April 24, 1989: In the preview issue for the [[1989 NFL Draft]], football player [[Tony Mandarich]] was featured on the cover, with the label of "best offensive line prospect ever."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/9169/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Most Popular | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref> Mandarich has been widely regarded as a bust in the NFL. In fact, he would appear on the cover again three years later under the headline "Incredible Bust".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/1004/nfl.draft.busts.modern.era/content.3.html | work=CNN | title=Tony Mandarich}}</ref> *May 8, 1989: Jon Peters of Brenham High School in Texas set the national high school record for games won by a pitcher, with a 51–0 record. The next game after the cover, he lost for the first (and only) time in his high school career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mentalfloss.com/blogs/archives/26197|title=Where Are They Now? High School Kids Immortalized By Sports Illustrated|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> *June 5, 1989: After the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] swept the [[Phoenix Suns]] in the NBA Western Conference Finals to go undefeated to that point in the playoffs, that week's cover featured Lakers forward [[James Worthy]] with the word "SWEEP!" in large letters and, in smaller letters, the caption: "James Worthy and the Lakers beat the Suns to go 11–0 in the playoffs." The Lakers would go on to lose in the [[1989 NBA Finals]], being swept 4–0 by the [[Detroit Pistons]] after losing starting guards [[Magic Johnson]] and [[Byron Scott]] to hamstring injuries.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/9175/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Most Popular}}</ref> *October 31, 1988: The cover featured Dodger pitcher Orel Hershiser on the cover just after the Dodgers won the World Series. That season Hershiser led the league in wins (23), innings (267), shutouts (8) and complete games (15). He was third in ERA at 2.26. He finished the season with a record 59 consecutive scoreless innings pitched, breaking the mark of 58 held by former Dodger Don Drysdale. He was selected to his second All-Star game and was a unanimous selection for the National League Cy Young Award. He also won the Gold Glove Award for the best fielding pitcher in the National League. Hershiser was also the only player to receive the Cy Young Award, the Championship Series MVP Award, and the World Series MVP Award in the same season. In 1990, it was discovered that Hershiser had a torn labrum in the shoulder of his pitching arm. Dr. Frank Jobe performed shoulder reconstruction surgery on Hershiser on April 27, 1990, the first time the procedure had been performed on a major league player. The Dodgers did not reach another World Series until 2017
===1990–2000=== *August 28, 1995: [[Keyshawn Johnson]] was featured on the cover, proclaiming why the [[USC Trojans football|USC Trojans]] would go back to no. 1. The Trojans finished with a 9–2–1 record while ending up being ranked no. 12, as they never reached the top three of the [[1995 NCAA Division I-A football rankings|polls]]. *September 14, 1996: As they had been in 1972, [[1996 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] was the two-time defending national champion and was heavily favored to win a third. This time, running back [[Ahman Green]] was pictured with the headline: "Red Alert: [[Ahman Green]] and [[1996 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] Set Their Sights on a Third Straight National Title." The following week, the Huskers were shut out for the first time since 1973, 19–0 by Arizona State. Despite this early loss, the Huskers were still in position to play for the national title late in the season before suffering a humiliating upset in the inaugural [[1996 Big 12 Championship Game|Big XII championship game]] to the 7–4 [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]]. *January 13, 1997: [[Mark Brunell]] of the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] and [[Kerry Collins]] of the [[Carolina Panthers]] appeared on the cover as their respective teams advance to the [[AFC Championship Game|AFC]] and [[NFC Championship Game]]s. Both teams lost. *March 3, 1997: [[Sugar Ray Leonard]] appeared on the cover days before his comeback fight against [[Héctor Camacho]]. Leonard would lose by TKO in the 5th round, ending his career. *February 2, 1998: [[Michelle Kwan]] appeared on the cover with the headline "The Gold Standard" shortly after winning the [[1998 U.S. Figure Skating Championships]] over rival [[Tara Lipinski]]. Weeks later she would lose the gold medal to Lipinski at the [[1998 Winter Olympics]] in one of the closest decisions in the history of women's Olympic figure skating. Later in [[2002 Winter Olympics|2002]] she would finish with a bronze medal while fellow American [[Sarah Hughes]] wins Gold. Finally injuries forced Michelle to retire prior to competing in the [[2006 Winter Olympics]]. *September 4, 2000: [[Ryan Leaf]] appeared on the cover with the headline "Back from the Brink" after a 24–20 win by his [[San Diego Chargers]] over the [[Arizona Cardinals]] characterizing his comeback as "an ascent from pariah to possible standout pro passer".<ref name="SI 2000">{{cite news|last=Silver|first=Michael|title=Recharged|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1020234/index.htm|work=Sports Illustrated|date=September 4, 2000}} Full-size image of cover [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/cover/featured/9756/index.htm here].</ref> This did not improve his team's performance during the season through Leaf's injuries and poor attitude, leading to his release, and ultimately, his career never recovered. *September 11, 2000: Painted in gold, gymnast [[Ivan Ivankov]] was on the cover of the Olympic preview issue with the caption, "The World's Best Gymnast."
